articles.trailText: While Nigel Farage promotes retro plans to reopen coalmines, will he really tell thousands of clean energy workers to leave their well-paid, local jobs, asks Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Labour’s climate minister Ed Miliband unveiled plans to create 400,000 green jobs by 2030 across 31 priority roles – from welders to production managers – supported by new academies in Lutterworth, Teesside decarbonisation hubs and clean-energy apprenticeships. With average wind-sector salaries at £51k versus £37k national, unions back project grants tied to enhanced recognition and fair-work charters. Miliband’s blueprint includes five technical excellence colleges, V-level reforms and a £300 energy-bill cut pledge, aiming to reengage nearly one million disengaged youth and counter Conservative and Reform UK’s anti-net-zero rhetoric. FE colleges like Crawley’s “green village” expect renewed investment in retraining and skills.

articles.title: Britain is suddenly pining for closer ties with the EU. It’s more likely to get the cold shoulder | Anand Menon
articles.trailText: Labour now wants to use the damage from Brexit to combat the threat of Nigel Farage, but the union has bigger fish to fry, says Anand Menon, director of UK in a Changing Europe
articles.summary: Labour’s government has shifted from cautious talk to an urgent push for an EU reset, touting Brexit’s economic damage to counter Nigel Farage and negotiating deals on fisheries, agrifoods, energy, defence and a new youth mobility scheme. Urgency is driven by upcoming budget forecasts, the EU’s carbon border tax from January 2026 and the need to join its new defence fund. But Brussels sees lower stakes, faces regulatory hurdles on alignment, numbers and fees, and resists doing Britain favours. UK enthusiasm risks collision with EU priorities, likely leading to frustration rather than quick wins.

articles.title: A 3,200km tour of small Australian libraries taught me just how vital they are | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: In the sleepiest towns I found bustling, light-filled places eager for conversations about books and writing
articles.summary: On a 3,200 km road-trip with crime novelist Michael Brissenden, Paul Daley found record-breaking engagement in regional and suburban Australian public libraries: 88 million in-person visits (up 10%), 119 million physical and 55 million digital loans, and 409,000 programs for over 7 million participants in 2023–24. Transformed into bright, conversation-friendly community hubs, libraries now host lively Q&As on writing craft, mentor aspiring authors, and provide free wifi and welcoming spaces—serving as an egalitarian social glue and lifeline for marginalised patrons.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the price of a prince: what Virginia Giuffre’s story says about palace accountability | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Jeffrey Epstein scandal has exposed a constitutional blind spot: royal privilege remains beyond democratic scrutiny. MPs must be able to question power
articles.summary: Virginia Giuffre’s allegations that Jeffrey Epstein trafficked her and forced her into sexual encounters with Prince Andrew—including at age 17—have reignited debate over royal immunity and accountability. Despite Andrew’s denials and a reported £12 million settlement funded by the late queen, parliamentary rules bar MPs from questioning the royals and only the crown can revoke titles—creating a self-referencing circle of deference. Since David Cameron’s 2011 funding overhaul tripled the sovereign grant and removed Commons oversight, Crown finances and roles escape democratic scrutiny. Lawmakers now press to restore parliamentary control over royal prerogatives and funding.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Ukraine peace talks: Europe must ensure Zelenskyy can resist Trump’s bullying | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US president’s attempts to broker a deal fail to distinguish between the aggressor and the victim. No just agreement is possible on that basis
articles.summary: During Zelenskiy’s recent White House visit, Donald Trump alternated between offering Tomahawk missiles and pressuring Kyiv to cede territory, framing Russia’s invasion as a real-estate dispute. Ahead of a possible US-Russia summit in Budapest under Orbán’s patronage, Europe must shore up Ukraine’s financial resilience—e.g. Merz’s £122bn frozen-assets loan plan—and find workarounds to Viktor Orbán’s EU veto. EU leaders at the Brussels summit should counter Trump’s mercurial “mediator” role and ensure Ukraine resists any deal rewarding Putin’s aggression.

articles.title: The massive No Kings protests may mark a new American political posture | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The violence Republicans seemed to want did not materialize. Instead the event showcased liberal-democratic consensus
articles.summary: The week-long No Kings protests, organized by a global coalition of liberal groups, defied predictions of violence by Republican leaders—Mike Johnson, Tom Emmer, Roger Marshall—who branded demonstrators as antifa, Marxists and terrorists. Instead, millions rallied peacefully in cities from New York to San Francisco, employing humor and irreverent costumes to mock Trump’s authoritarianism. Diverse participants—from democratic socialists to libertarians—united under a common goal: restore liberal-democratic norms and rebuild constitutional protections. The movement’s capacious, joyous tone suggests a new left-liberal popular front, melding principle with irreverence in sustained opposition to the Trump regime.

articles.title: What do we learn from Epstein and Andrew? There’s a level of power at which right and wrong no longer exist | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Prince Andrew has finally decided to give up his titles – but we have known the shape of the allegations against him for years. Why was there a collective decision to look away, asks Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Facing fresh revelations in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir Nobody’s Girl, Prince Andrew announced he will relinquish his Duke of York title and Order of the Garter after decades of sex-trafficking allegations linked to Jeffrey Epstein. Despite denying all claims, his 2011 email to Epstein—signed “A, HRH the Duke of York, KG”—and Giuffre’s detailed account of underage sex have long undermined his credibility. Lawmakers now call for royal title removal powers. Critics argue society enabled his impunity, choosing to look away until public pressure mounted. Zoe Williams contends this saga exposes how extreme privilege can blur moral boundaries and shelter the powerful from accountability.

articles.title: What the menopause marketers won’t tell you: ageing is to be celebrated | Stella Duffy
articles.trailText: Advertisers exploit our misogynistic culture, making women feel as if their bodies are broken. But better information might just help, says writer Stella Duffy
articles.summary: Duffy argues advertisers exploit misogynistic, ageist and pronatalist fears in a “menopause gold rush,” leaving many unsure whom to trust. An Australian study of over 500 women aged 45–64 found widespread skepticism toward pharmaceutical motives. Recounting severe symptoms during chemo and IVF, she frames menopause as a physiological transition akin to puberty or parenthood. Marketing tactics fuel a divide between MHT and non-MHT camps; research shows no universal menopause: symptoms and attitudes vary by lifestyle, culture and bias. In cultures valuing older women, symptoms ease. Postmenopause, lasting a third of life, becomes a vibrant “third act” if guided by accurate information.

articles.title: When my kids wrote a song using AI, all I could think was: you missed the fun part | Myke Bartlett
articles.trailText: The arrival of AI is a chance to remind kids that the joy of creativity is not in what you made, but in the process of making it
articles.summary: When columnist Myke Bartlett’s preteens use ChatGPT to write a song, skipping the playful drafting stage, he realises they’ve lost the joyous pursuit of creativity. He warns that AI shortcuts reinforce a focus on outcomes over process, risking human redundancy in writing, art and beyond. Bartlett argues that true creative growth lies in experimentation, failure and craft, not instant results. He urges parents to help children value ‘endurance artistry’—the struggle and discovery that shape thinkers and makers—reminding us that the essence of creativity is in doing, not just having created.

articles.title: I never wash our bread knife – and I won’t let the internet shame me into changing my ways | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Apparently the mostly British habit of not cleaning your bread knife after use is ‘gross’ and unhygienic. If that’s true, then call me disgusting, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington rejects online shaming over her habit of not thoroughly washing her bread knife, arguing that a quick wipe and storage on a crumb-laden breadboard is harmless and reflects a common British shortcut. Her 2025 column highlights social media moral panics branding such practices “gross,” mocks contrived hygiene controversies—from knives and phone screens to sheets, towels, bras and sports kit—and celebrates her “robust medieval peasant microbiome.” She urges fellow self-described slatterns to resist disgust emojis and embrace relaxed cleaning routines, while still offering guests fresh sheets.

articles.title: Troops on the streets, Ice thuggery – and prices still climbing: welcome to Trump’s ‘golden age’ | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: The president has repeatedly proclaimed a shining moment. Meanwhile, he’s taking a wrecking ball to truth and democracy
articles.summary: Trump’s second term, billed as America’s 'golden age,' belies a federal shutdown, deep polarization and stalled job growth. He’s deployed the National Guard and ICE in cities, sparking teargas, arrests and accusations of thuggery. Polls show 58% disapproval and 62% say the nation is off track. Tariffs have fueled inflation and stalled manufacturing, while 10 million risk losing health coverage and 22 million face premium spikes. Science cuts and vaccine skepticism spurred a measles resurgence. Justice Dept politicization and plunging international approval (91% in Mexico) underscore a dark, not golden, age enriching gilders and billionaires.

articles.title: It’s still killing people, and the government has yet to act: Britain’s hidden asbestos epidemic | Tom White
articles.trailText: Asbestos was banned in 1999, but as materials left in our buildings deteriorate, thousands of lives are being lost every year, says writer and education worker Tom White
articles.summary: Despite a 1999 ban, Britain still records around 5,000 asbestos-related deaths annually (possibly up to 20,000), as ageing insulation in 78% of surveyed buildings continues to release deadly fibres. Mesothelioma’s long latency has spawned a third wave of cases, exemplified by 38-year-old Helen Bone’s fatal diagnosis. Current in-situ management rules let damaged crocidolite and amosite persist in schools, hospitals and homes—71% of materials are damaged, 30% high-risk—without coordinated removal. Unlike South Korea’s and Australia’s national eradication plans, the UK lacks a funded strategy. Campaigners demand a mass retrofit and removal programme backed by government and grassroots coalitions.

articles.title: A-level English, voluntary work, delayed citizenship: it’s Labour’s Orwellian Two Minutes Hate for immigrants  | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: It’s easier for politicians to blame others than to face the truth: Britain has been stripped of the spaces and opportunities that allow for true social integration, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik criticises Labour’s escalating immigration pledges—English A-level exams, mandatory volunteer work, and a ten-year route to citizenship—as punitive, symbolic gestures that scapegoat migrants for Britain’s erosion of social cohesion. She argues true integration depends on public services—libraries, community centres, youth clubs and adequately resourced schools and hospitals—hollowed out by austerity. By imposing arbitrary benchmarks on “skilled” and “high-potential” migrants, politicians evade addressing societal fragmentation and fuel nationalist sentiment. Malik calls for real investment in shared spaces and mockingly proposes a cricket Test match for migrants vying for citizenship.

articles.title: In Gaza, and now Ukraine, Donald Trump may be peace activists' greatest ally. That deserves our backing | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: It’s a fool’s game trying to understand the president’s true motives, but do our misgivings matter if the outcome is a speedy end to war, asks Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: By leveraging his recent Gaza ceasefire, Donald Trump is pressing for an immediate Ukraine ceasefire, rejecting Zelenskiy’s plea for more Tomahawks and urging both sides to halt fighting, return home and negotiate. Jenkins argues Trump’s unpredictability and minimal reliance on traditional diplomacy may open stalled conflicts to resolution. His approach prioritizes swift peace over ideology or consistency, promising guarantees along existing frontlines without US troop deployment. He contrasts this with Western inaction, Biden’s cautious limits on aid and NATO’s drift, suggesting Trump’s raw dealmaking can break stalemates where allies have failed. If successful, his personal charisma could end two bitter wars. We should support any outcome that stops the killing.

articles.title: Tony Abbott’s argument about Australian democracy is Trumpian in intent and based on half-truths | Marcia Langton
articles.trailText: Former PM’s new book reads like a style manual for March for Australia types, weaving together evidence and myth, history and ideology
articles.summary: Marcia Langton critiques former PM Tony Abbott’s Australia, A History as a strategic ‘style manual’ for the March for Australia movement. While some historians praise its compelling narrative, Langton exposes ideological sleights: Abbott’s global CPAC speeches champion Trump 2.0 and white British Christian nationalism, misattributes fire-stick farming, downplays colonial massacres, distorts immigration debates and undermines Indigenous recognition by recasting Welcome to Country and the Aboriginal flag as divisive. She argues his blend of strong scholarship and selective mythmaking deliberately reinforces a parochial British-rooted identity, weaponising half-truths to defend his conservative agenda and reshape Australian democracy.

articles.title: America, there is still so much to love about you but we have to break up. This is why I’m renouncing US citizenship | Anonymous
articles.trailText: A menacing portrait of Donald Trump at the US consulate in Sydney is the final push. I know I am making the right choice
articles.summary: An Australian-based “accidental American” with deep family roots dating to 1636 describes renouncing her US citizenship after 60 years of inherited ties. Though she cherishes America’s national parks, cultural memories and family legacy, the author cites “citizen insecurity” amid today’s political climate and onerous US tax-filing requirements for expatriates as untenable. At Sydney’s US consulate, under a menacing Trump portrait, she pays US$2,350, swears an oath free of coercion, and receives her renunciation certificate and hole-punched passport. She hopes for future visas but feels liberated from tax stress and disconnection.

articles.title: The Guardian view on hybrid cars: profitable for carmakers but not very green | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Plug-in hybrids pollute more than their manufacturers claim – and delay the real shift to electric and shared mobility
articles.summary: Editorial warns plug-in hybrids emit just 19% less CO2 in real world versus 75% in lab, yet are lucrative bolt-on petrol models that delay EV adoption. EU firms dodged €5bn fines by testing in labs; UK plans to weaken EV targets risk scandal. Chinese BYD leads Europe's EV market below £20k, outpacing Tesla amid political backlash. Toyota's promised solid-state batteries by 2027 could disrupt low-cost lithium tech. It also warns that EV-only focus ignores congestion, road deaths and minerals equity, calling for a just transition.

articles.title: The Guardian view on childbirth and medical negligence: rising payouts highlight the urgency of maternity improvements
articles.trailText: Grave shortcomings in the care offered to mothers and babies are well documented. But it is not clear that the right lessons have been learned
articles.summary: Rising NHS negligence payouts, now estimated at £60 billion, expose chronic failures in England’s maternity services: obstetric awards quadrupled in 20 years due to costly lifetime care for injured infants. High-profile scandals (Morecambe Bay, Shrewsbury & Telford, East Kent) revealed poor leadership, understaffing, weak oversight and cultural resistance to learning. Two-thirds of units require improvement; maternal mortality, severe tears and readmissions have increased while 2015 targets to halve deaths slip. Health Secretary Wes Streeting’s promised review demands enforceable reforms amid demographic shifts (older, heavier mothers, more C-sections) and workforce strains.

articles.title: Spirituality isn’t rigid dogma. It’s a living, breathing practice that helps make sense of an incomprehensible world | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: I grew up in Kabul and Karachi. In both, I learned the value of the quiet rituals observed while no one is watching
articles.summary: Drawing on childhood memories in Kabul and Karachi, Shadi Khan Saif shows how quiet rituals—throwing water for safe journeys, hanging black cloths, burning esfand or tying taweez—offer grounding, protection and hope beyond formal religion. These gestures, passed from women to girls (and attentive boys), embed spirituality in daily life, surviving war, migration and change. Settled in Melbourne, she still whispers Ayatul Kursi before flights and avoids sweeping at night, keeping ancestral habits alive. Saif argues that such intimate, living practices—echoed in Indigenous chanting circles and rituals worldwide—help humans find peace in a chaotic world.

articles.title: Bravo to the judges speaking the truth to Trump in Chicago and Portland | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: District courts are speaking truth to power over troop deployments. If only the supreme court would do the same
articles.summary: Steven Greenhouse applauds federal judges Karin Immergut and April Perry for rejecting Trump’s “untethered” claims that Portland and Chicago were “war-ravaged” zones requiring troop deployments. Both judges found no evidence of rebellion or significant violence beyond routine protests, blocked national guard missions, and were vindicated by appellate panels. Greenhouse contrasts their clear-eyed rulings with the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority, which he criticizes for habitual deference to Trump’s false assertions and power grabs. He urges the high court to emulate lower courts’ courage in upcoming cases on tariffs, deportations, and executive authority to safeguard constitutional limits and democracy.

articles.title: The lavender marriage is back – but why? | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: People are taking many new and unexpected approaches to matrimony, and it is surprisingly exciting, says Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington explores the revival of the "lavender marriage"—a term once denoting Hollywood PR unions between closeted gay stars—to describe modern committed partnerships that sidestep conventional romance or sexual attraction. She highlights examples like gay-straight pair Jacob Hoff and Samantha Greenstone, and asexual couple April Lexi Lee and Sheree Wong, who formalize their deep friendship as marriage (also dubbed Platonic Life Partnerships or "rainbow marriage" online). Beddington argues these unions deliver economic, legal, emotional and health benefits, reflect Gen Z's dating fatigue and fiscal pressures, and challenge narrow definitions of love and marriage.

articles.title: A waiting list of thousands, and just five new homes for social rent: this city shows the depth of Britain’s housing crisis | John Harris
articles.trailText: Liverpool was once praised for its tolerance, but housing shortages are driving fearful, unsettling behaviours – and people are blaming outsiders, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Liverpool faces acute housing crisis: 12,764 households on social housing waiting list but only five new social-rent dwellings built in 2023–24. Homelessness support applications rose 25% to 2,048. Private rents climbed 9.6% in a year, driving evictions and food-bank queues. Asylum seekers lose Home Office accommodation within weeks, increasing street living. Residents like an ambulance worker and rough sleepers describe mouldy homes or confiscated tents. City council’s plan for 30,000 new homes over 15 years includes just 10% social rent, while national promises of 180,000 homes by 2036 and renters’ rights reforms offer limited relief. Rising xenophobic blame highlights social tensions.

articles.title: Xi Jinping is preparing to go toe to toe with Donald Trump – and there will only be one winner | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: Beijing has realised that reckless America First policies are alienating old and new friends alike, creating a vacuum it can fill, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: At the Sharm el-Sheikh summit Trump’s self-congratulations masked waning US influence. Beijing has seized on his America First missteps to sprint ahead in the global primacy race. Xi Jinping has weaponised China’s near-monopoly on rare-earth exports with stricter controls, threatening Western arms supplies to Ukraine and jolting markets. While Trump rattles off tariff threats without a coherent strategy, Xi extends trade pacts via BRICS, African tariff waivers and new UN initiatives, filling vacuums left by the US retreat. Britain, marginalized by both powers, risks becoming collateral damage in this intensifying Sino-American duel.

articles.title: Spare us from romcom Austen. Give me the dark side of 19th-century life any day | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: Why sanitise or sugarcoat the classics? New adaptations of Austen and Brontë could explore everything from slavery to death in childbirth, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett welcomes Andrew Davies’s intent to mine Jane Austen’s darker subplots in his new adaptations of Emma, Mansfield Park and The Watsons—exposing slavery on Bertram plantations, death in childbirth and other unspoken 19th-century realities. She argues that modern screenwriters sanitise classics into rom-coms, and calls instead for gritty period drama—citing Joe Wright’s muddy Pride and Prejudice and other social-realist productions. While embracing Brontë’s gothic violence, she warns against gratuitous shock, dubbing Emerald Fennell’s Wuthering Heights opener “appalling” yet affirming her appetite to see its bold take.

articles.title: My dad cursed our family and left us. But after his death, he followed me everywhere | Jonas Hassen Khemiri
articles.trailText: His absence shaped me. But as my father lay dying in a Stockholm nursing home, I longed to hear him explain, says Swedish novelist Jonas Hassen Khemiri
articles.summary: Jonas Hassen Khemiri traces his father’s journey—from a young Tunisian store detective who met his Swedish mother in a Lausanne mall and believed their shared surname meant “mountain man,” to a man abandoned by his wife who cursed his three sons. Diagnosed with Lewy body dementia, he suffered hallucinations and paranoia in a Stockholm nursing home. Khemiri and his brothers gathered for palliative care, sharing stories and music, yet he died without reconciliation. In the months after his 2025 death, Khemiri encountered vivid reappearances of his father in New York and Tunis, reflecting on storytelling as a bulwark against loss and absence.

articles.title: My essay about childhood heroes was in this year’s HSC English exam – it made me rethink who mine really were | Deirdre Fidge
articles.trailText: Everyone warned me against choosing humanities-heavy subjects – but these classes opened my mind and excited me in ways that still affect me today
articles.summary: After discovering her teenage essay about childhood hero She-Ra was used in this year’s HSC English exam prompt "How does Fidge explore the impact of role models?", Deirdre Fidge reflects on her own VCE journey. Despite advice to avoid humanities and worry over subject scaling, she credits English language and literature teachers—Mrs Feeney and Mrs Di Stefano—for igniting her passion through lively grammar debates and immersive readings. She urges students to pursue subjects that excite them, nurturing their energy and curiosity.

articles.title: Albanese faces the diplomatic test of his political life to attract, and hold, Trump’s attention | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: Dealing with the US president requires nose holding; and the PM must navigate the delicate balance between getting Trump’s attention and attracting too much
articles.summary: PM Anthony Albanese faces a high-stakes challenge to woo Donald Trump—a US president largely indifferent to Australia beyond defence ties and Crocodile Dundee. Securing a meeting means balancing visibility and avoiding domestic backlash over costly pacts like AUKUS. Winning Trump requires a self-interested deal—US investment in Australian critical minerals, framing AUKUS as zero-cost to Americans—and seizing shared support for an Israel-Hamas ceasefire. Albanese must navigate Trump’s mercurial cues, set aside criticism of his policies, yet uphold Australian values to preserve credibility. Success hinges on decisive leadership, strategic bargaining and deft political nose-holding to keep Trump engaged.

articles.title: A congressman’s ex got a protective order against him. His boss has little to say about it | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: This isn’t the first time Cory Mills has faced allegations of misconduct – but the House speaker wants to talk about ‘serious’ things
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi's Guardian column dismantles Florida GOP congressman Cory Mills—an anti-abortion, anti-immigrant, pro-Trump firebrand—after a judge granted a protective order to his ex-girlfriend Lindsey Langston, citing credible threats to release nude images and potential violence. Langston also alleged Mills violated dating-violence protections, while another woman’s assault claim and his failed $85k rent payments have attracted police and landlord actions. A House ethics probe over his military-contract interests adds to the controversies, yet Speaker Mike Johnson merely calls for “serious” topics. Mahdawi links Mills’s saga to broader GOP family-values hypocrisy, then touches on Costa Rica abortion curbs, Virginia Giuffre’s memoir extract and culture items.

articles.title: Shorn of title, status and dignity, it’s the new Prince Andrew. A life he was born to replaced by a life he will hate | Stephen Bates
articles.trailText: Nothing will ever be the same for the disgraced royal or the other Windsors. He can still live in Royal Lodge, but it’s a terrible blow to his sense of entitlement, says former Guardian royal correspondent Stephen Bates
articles.summary: Prince Andrew, stripped of his Duke of York title and Knight of the Garter status—and barred from using them—faces a collapse of entitlement and public standing. While privately retaining Royal Lodge residency and naval pension, he forfeits public funding, royal duties, and family engagements, relegated to solitary routines with ex-wife Sarah Ferguson and cut off from key events like Sandringham Christmas and future coronations. With potential further damage from Epstein files, the embattled eighth-in-line endures financial uncertainty and social isolation, forced into a diminished life he loathes.

articles.title: Gaza’s children needed a ceasefire – now they desperately need the aid that will keep them alive | Alison Griffin
articles.trailText: The youngest and most vulnerable have suffered extreme mental and physical trauma. We can help – but we must be granted immediate access, says Alison Griffin of Save the Children UK
articles.summary: Alison Griffin of Save the Children UK warns that Gaza’s temporary ceasefire has eased immediate fear but children still face catastrophic malnutrition, disease and trauma amid insufficient aid access. Since March, Save the Children supplies have been repeatedly blocked; Gaza needs at least 600 aid trucks daily, 50 fuel tankers and cooking gas to meet basic rights. With winter nearing and 92% of homes destroyed, urgent unimpeded access, an international mechanism at Rafah and a permanent ceasefire are vital. Besides food, water and shelter, children need mental health support, schooling for 700,000 pupils and long-term specialist care for amputees.

articles.title: Shows such as Stranger Things and Yellowjackets have become bloated. I’m all for the one-and-done series | Priya Elan
articles.trailText: Fans who moan when a show is axed after its first season should be careful what they wish for. If only my TV obsession had ended a long time ago, says arts writer Priya Elan
articles.summary: Priya Elan argues that many serialized TV franchises lose momentum and narrative focus beyond their inaugural season, urging a return to “one-and-done” formats. She cites Yellowjackets—a 10-episode 1996-plane-crash drama starring Juliette Lewis, Lauren Ambrose and Sophie Thatcher—whose planned five seasons were cut to four amid concerns over bloat from side characters like Shauna’s daughter Callie. Elan faults sequels of Stranger Things, Emily in Paris, Squid Game and House of the Dragon for clichés, while praising limited series such as Sharp Objects, I May Destroy You, Adolescence and 1990s cult classic My So-Called Life. She warns against reviving limited hits like Big Little Lies when the story has run its course.

articles.title: A prophetic 1934 novel has found a surprising second life – it holds lessons for us all | Charlotte Higgins
articles.trailText: Sally Carson’s Crooked Cross was written and set during the rise of nazism. It shows both how extremism takes hold, and the moral certainty needed to resist it, says the Guardian’s chief culture writer, Charlotte Higgins
articles.summary: Rediscovered by Persephone Books, Sally Carson’s 1934 novel Crooked Cross charts the six months from December 1932 to summer 1933 in the fictional Bavarian town of Kranach, following the Kluger family’s Christmas reunion as Hitler’s influence grows. Through domestic detail—party games, Helmy’s portrait of Hitler—and mounting horrors at Dachau, Carson diagnoses how economic collapse and a search for purpose drew moderate Germans toward Nazism. Her immediate, morally urgent narrative, written as events unfolded, resonates in 2025 as a cautionary tale about the seductions of extremism and the necessity of clear-eyed resistance.

articles.title: Critical thinking is one of the most important aspects of being human, according to Stoicism. So why are we handing it over to a machine? | Brigid Delaney
articles.trailText: All of us, no matter what our circumstances, have the ability to be more wise, more just, more courageous and more moderate
articles.summary: Brigid Delaney argues that Stoicism’s ancient guideposts—rationality, virtue and acceptance of fate—offer tools to navigate 21st-century crises from AI threats to economic collapse, political polarisation and climate anxiety. Drawing on Marcus Aurelius, Seneca and Epictetus, she urges facing reality honestly, preserving critical thinking against automation, preparing for material loss through voluntary discomfort, fostering social cohesion through mutual forbearance, and leading by embodying wisdom, courage, temperance and justice. Stoicism reminds us that while many external events lie beyond control, we can always cultivate character and judgement.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and the law: a restraint on the executive is morphing into its weapon | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The indictment of critics including John Bolton rings alarm bells as the US president expands his power and seeks to use the justice system to exact revenge
articles.summary: The Guardian warns that Donald Trump, emboldened by last year’s supreme court ruling on presidential immunity, is morphing US law from a check on executive power into a political weapon. By stacking courts, pardoning January 6 rioters, ignoring judicial restraints and pushing prosecutions of critics such as John Bolton, Letitia James and James Comey, Trump seeks vengeance via the justice system. Experts warn of “competitive authoritarianism” as undermining democracy. With No Kings protests looming, the administration casts dissent as disorder, while a survey finds a third of Republicans support deporting opponents. Such weaponisation of law is the real emergency.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Austen and Brontë adaptations: purists may reel, but reinvention keeps classic novels alive | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The appetite for onscreen versions of much-loved literature is endless, but dogged faithfulness to a text is not the only way to stay true to authors’ spirit
articles.summary: Editorial contends that adaptations of Austen and Brontë—like Andrew Davies’s upcoming Emma and Mansfield Park with themes of death, debauchery and slavery, or Emerald Fennell’s provocative, hyper-erotic Wuthering Heights—reveal darker novelistic undercurrents often missed. Since Colin Firth’s 1995 Pride and Prejudice, viewers expect heightened tension, and recent casting choices for Heathcliff ignite debates on authenticity. Reimaginings from Wide Sargasso Sea to Clueless prove that reinvention fuels engagement, keeps classics culturally vital and draws new readers, countering fears of literary desecration by sustaining these works in public conversation.

articles.title: Donald Trump claims to be the president of peace, but at home he is fomenting civil war | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: His ruthless use of the national guard to menace cities and political enemies is unprecedented. He is preparing for battle against the ‘enemy within’, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland argues Donald Trump’s self-styled role as international peacemaker—citing a fragile Gaza ceasefire and planned Putin summit—belies his domestic strategy: deploying the National Guard to low-crime, Democrat-run cities to intimidate opposition, normalize troops ahead of midterms and justify emergency powers. He’s recast the military to counter an “enemy within,” weaponized the justice system against critics and purged federal agencies of dissenters. Freedland warns these moves risk sparking a second American civil war under the guise of public order.

articles.title: Trump is battling the ravages of Time – in more ways than one | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: The president is upset with his photo on the magazine’s cover. I, too, have a bone to pick with my scalp
articles.summary: Humorist Dave Schilling links his own thinning hair woes to Trump’s latest outburst over Time’s cover photo—shot from below, accentuating his neck crease and making his trademark yellow wave look wispy. The piece traces Trump’s fixation on appearance, from a derided presidential portrait to Truth Social tirades, and frames it as a battle against ageing. Schilling wryly notes the booming market for hair-growth remedies and suggests Trump could turn this insecurity into another profit-driven endorsement.

articles.title: Punish Prince Andrew? This is no meritocracy, I’m afraid – you get the royal family you didn’t vote for | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: After years of drip-fed revelations, we might as well face it. This is a family elevated by birthright: they’re stuck with him and so are we, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde argues that the British monarchy is inherently non-meritocratic, illustrated by Prince Andrew’s continued privileges despite his alleged sex offences and ties to Jeffrey Epstein. While victims in his Epstein-associated orbit have died or been jailed, Andrew lives in a 30-room mansion, shrugging off fresh revelations—emails proving his post-Epstein correspondence and meetings with a Chinese spy suspect. Hyde ridicules proposed sanctions (losing Garter lunch, counsellor-of-state role) as tokenism, and warns that firing a royal risks undermining the monarchy’s very raison d’être.

articles.title: The sale of the Telegraph is no trivial matter. A mainstream media further exploited by the right threatens us all | Jane Martinson
articles.trailText: It’s more than just the Tory house bible. On multiple ethical and political grounds, Lisa Nandy must think hard before nodding any deal through, says Guardian columnist Jane Martinson
articles.summary: Jane Martinson urges culture secretary Lisa Nandy to launch a fresh public interest review into RedBird Capital’s £500m bid for Telegraph Media Group, warning that opaque private equity and Gulf-state funding—from Sheikh Mansour’s IMI (now capped at 15%) to tech billionaires—threaten editorial independence. Founder Gerry Cardinale’s vision of a “New York Times of the right” risks partisan bias and profit-driven cost cuts, echoing past Barclay sales and US conglomerate deals like Paramount-Skydance. Enforceable governance and transparency are essential to safeguard quality journalism against disinformation and foreign influence.

articles.title: Trump’s peace plan is just about holding together, but may be unravelled by two unresolved issues | Rajan Menon
articles.trailText: The withdrawal of Israeli troops and the establishment of an International Stabilisation force are key in securing long term peace, but the plan is dangerously vague on these issues, says professor of international relations Rajan Menon
articles.summary: Trump’s 20-point plan brokered a Gaza ceasefire, initial Israeli pullback and aid corridors, but its long-term viability hinges on two vague provisions: phased IDF withdrawals and an international stabilisation force. The roadmap lacks timelines, enforcement or verification for reducing Israel’s presence from over 50% to 40% then 15%, inviting disputes with Hamas, which demands full exit and refuses disarmament absent guarantees. Similarly, the plan outlines a peacekeeping mission without size, mandate or member commitments. These gaps undermine trust, risk ceasefire collapse and threaten the plan’s broader goals of reconstruction and governance.

articles.title: Maga is painting Saturday’s protests as violent treason. Prove them wrong | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: Trump allies would love an excuse to step up their crackdown. Nonviolence, both disciplined and open-hearted, must define the day
articles.summary: Judith Levine warns against Republican slander of the nationwide No Kings protests on October 18 as violent “Hate America” and “antifa” rallies, part of a disinformation campaign under Trump’s domestic-terrorism memo. She highlights DHS/FBI bulletins linking lawful demonstrations to violence and fears armed vigilantes or federal forces will provoke clashes to justify a crackdown or invoke the Insurrection Act. Levine urges disciplined nonviolence—championed by Indivisible and partner groups—as a strategic, moral resistance to expose the real aggressors.

articles.title: Trump’s anti-truth crusade is not just an attack on facts – it’s an unravelling of the Enlightenment | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The US president, JD Vance and Nigel Farage seem to believe that checking facts is a form of censorship. Nonsense: speech is only free when it is anchored in truth, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee warns that Donald Trump, JD Vance and Nigel Farage are framing fact-checking as censorship, weakening Enlightenment values by denying objective truth. Tech giants Meta and Google have cut funding for Full Fact and scrapped ClaimReview, opting for crowd-sourced “community notes.” Full Fact’s CEO Chris Morris defends fact-checking as clarity rather than restriction, highlighting its work on scams, medical misinformation and tracking government promises. The dispute fuels debates over the UK’s Online Safety Act, as independent checkers stand as a vital bulwark against the surge of unreason.

articles.title: Millennial dads are experiencing something mums have known for a long time | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: Men want to be active, engaged parents, but many are being torn apart by the competing demands of family and work, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Working Families’ survey of 5,000 UK fathers finds 75% want to share parenting equally but face cultural and workplace obstacles—being questioned why their partner isn’t handling family needs, doubted on leave urgency, and fearful of professional backlash. Despite shared parental leave rights, many men remain breadwinner-minded and underutilise leave, with one-third wanting more paternity time and 80% feeling judged for prioritising family. YouGov data show some millennial men believe women have it easier, revealing bitterness. At the Equal Parenting conference, a “parent out loud” campaign was proposed to normalise men taking full leave and help both sexes find solidarity in juggling work and childcare.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the US and Venezuela: Trump’s ‘war on drugs’ ramps up military threats to Maduro | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Hawks want regime change. Democrats and others are right to warn against illegal and unauthorised use of force
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that Trump’s intensifying ‘war on drugs’ in Venezuela—approved CIA covert actions, extrajudicial Caribbean strikes killing 27 alleged drug traffickers and a 6,500-strong troop buildup—signals hawkish calls for regime change against Nicolás Maduro. Despite evidence that most fentanyl enters the US from Mexico, administration figures like Marco Rubio and Stephen Miller press for more forceful measures, sidelining envoy Richard Grenell’s diplomatic deals. Last week’s Nobel for opposition leader María Corina Machado offers symbolic support but is unlikely to unseat Maduro. Democrats and human rights groups caution against illegal interventions that imperil Venezuelan civilians and risk regional escalation.

articles.title: The Guardian view on UK national security: a case of state failure | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: This week’s partisan blame game is the wrong response to the collapse of the alleged Chinese spying case. The failure of governance runs deeper
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues that the collapse of an alleged Chinese spying prosecution exposed deep governance failures in the UK state. A case crucial to national security was abandoned under mysterious circumstances, eroding public confidence and overshadowed by partisan blame at Westminster. The piece criticises reliance on the century-old Official Secrets Act 1911 in a modern threat landscape, despite reforms under the National Security Act 2023. It also highlights a misjudged balance between government and the independent Crown Prosecution Service. Urgent legal and procedural reforms are needed to restore trust and ensure robust handling of future security cases.

articles.title: The latest Prince Andrew abuse claims are a new low for the Royal Family brand. In this form, it can’t survive | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: ‘The Firm’ as a modernising strategy was already falling apart, but with the shocking allegations so fully in the public domain, it has now collapsed, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins argues that Prince Andrew’s latest abuse allegations have fatally undermined the modern ‘Firm’ brand engineered by Elizabeth II in the 1960s. He highlights monarchy’s dependence on public consent—citing Edward VIII’s abdication, the 1992 ‘annus horribilis’ and Diana’s death—and warns that Andrew’s Epstein links further erode legitimacy. Contrasting Britain’s family-focused model with Scandinavian figurehead systems, Jenkins urges Prince William to streamline the institution: dissolve the ‘Firm’, relinquish London estates, embrace modesty and free royal offspring from official duties to restore public trust.

articles.title: When my daughter eats, it is with joyful abandon. Her behaviour is helping me unlearn toxic standards for women | Léa Antigny
articles.trailText: Watching my daughter’s strong sense of self has forced me to reflect on my own adolescence through the wildly misogynistic early 2000s
articles.summary: Léa Antigny describes her four-year-old daughter’s uninhibited, whole-body joy in eating as a powerful counterpoint to the toxic, moralized standards women internalize around food and desire. Recalling early-2000s misogynistic pop culture, diet fads and her own self-loathing, she commits to unlearning these lessons by modeling self-respect, rejecting ‘good’ or ‘naughty’ food talk and honoring her daughter’s autonomy—even in picky phases—to build resilience and mutual confidence.

articles.title: While the eyes of the world are on Gaza, Israeli settlers in the West Bank still behave with impunity | Ofer Cassif
articles.trailText: As the harvest season begins, attacks on Palestinian farmers and their land are spiralling. The words of peace following the Gaza ceasefire ring hollow, says Knesset member Ofer Cassif
articles.summary: Knesset member Ofer Cassif denounces unchecked settler violence in the West Bank rising during olive harvest season, with over 30 attacks since Trump’s 20-point plan announcement and 113 incidents in 2024 recorded by Yesh Din. He highlights complicity of Israeli security forces and COGAT units in blocking Palestinian farmers, and Bezalel Smotrich’s role in advancing settlement expansion. Despite UK sanctions on Smotrich, settlement produce still enters markets. Cassif argues only Palestinian state recognition, meaningful sanctions and sustained international pressure can end occupation and impunity.

articles.title: My teachers had no idea I was homeless. People like me hide in plain sight in the UK  | Isra Sulevani
articles.trailText: The housing crisis has reached catastrophic new levels, and Labour is planning to slash affordable housing even further. It doesn’t have to be this way, says medical student Isra Sulevani
articles.summary: Medical student Isra Sulevani recounts her hidden childhood homelessness—shuttling between B&Bs and friends’ homes, living in cold, cramped rooms with rats—until free school meals during the pandemic exposed her family’s plight. New figures show over 132,000 English households (172,000 children) in temporary accommodation, linked to 74 child deaths, and 1.3 million households on social housing waiting lists. Despite Labour’s promise to end homelessness and child poverty, no strategy has emerged and affordable housing targets may be cut. Sulevani, now a Crisis campaigner, calls for urgent delivery of a plan to build social homes and overhaul welfare so every family can live with dignity.

articles.title: The US supreme court appears ready to nullify the Voting Rights Act | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Court has repeatedly expanded states’ leeway to make voting laws that would have previously been deemed discriminatory
articles.summary: At oral arguments in Louisiana v. Callais, the US Supreme Court signaled it will dismantle Section 2 of the 1965 Voting Rights Act—the last federal guard against racial gerrymandering—by siding with “non-African-American” plaintiffs who claim majority-Black district maps violate their Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendment rights. This step completes a Roberts court campaign, begun with Shelby County v. Holder (2013), to eviscerate civil-rights protections. If affirmed, federal safeguards against Black vote dilution vanish, likely enabling new racial gerrymanders that could cost Democrats up to 19 House seats in the 2026 midterms.

articles.title: My mum died this year. And the glut of apples from her tree has brought with it a new kind of grief | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Every year, I refused the crates of fruit she tried to palm off on me each autumn. Now I wish I’d taken them, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: After her mother’s death, columnist Zoe Williams confronts a surplus of apples from her mum’s prolific tree. She recalls how she once refused the oversized crates—dismissing her mother’s famously haphazard cooking experiments that fused random ingredients like dried apricots in savory dishes—only to find herself now turning the glut into football-sized crumbles, flapjacks and other apple-heavy treats. Each bite brings a fresh pang of grief and a rueful reminder: enjoy your mother’s apples while she’s alive.

articles.title: In Gaza, we are picking up our lives amid the remnants of war, fear of Israel’s return haunting every step | Sondos Sabra
articles.trailText: There is a continuing trauma and new threats to our safety from gangs who terrorise us. Our ordeal has changed, but it’s far from over, says Gaza-based writer and translator Sondos Sabra
articles.summary: In Gaza’s aftermath, writer Sondos Sabra describes returning among rubble and unexploded munitions as neighbours tentatively rebuild amid daily trauma. Death became routine; now new threats arise from armed gangs exploiting power vacuums—seeded, some say, by Israel—to instill chaos and dismantle social bonds. Children wander among grenades; a toddler names fruit for the first time. Despite a fragile ceasefire, blockade and occupation endure, with settlements and oppression unrelenting. Gaza yearns to reclaim morning rituals, poetry and hope, but fear of resumed bombardment haunts every step.

articles.title: We are told the ‘war’ against Gaza is finally ‘over’. Is it? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: I am not celebrating the end of the ‘war’ because this was not a war – and it’s not over, either
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi argues the declared end of the Gaza ‘war’ masks ongoing atrocities and genocide. She cites UN satellite data showing 90% of homes, 95% of schools and 97% of crops destroyed, and an estimated 20,000 children killed. She highlights continued West Bank settler violence, arbitrary detentions and an “Israeli-style ceasefire” that still permits deadly fire. Media dehumanization—from Bill Maher’s jokes to US propaganda campaigns—and political rhetoric of “peace” serve expulsion, not coexistence. Genuine peace, Mahdawi insists, requires recognizing Palestinians’ humanity, ending dehumanization and ensuring accountability and justice.

articles.title: Wage war on nature to build new homes: that’s Labour’s offer, but it’s a con trick  | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: The government’s new planning bill is tearing down environmental protections to benefit developers. This nation of nature lovers won’t stand for it, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot lambasts Labour’s new planning and infrastructure bill as a ‘con trick’ that tears down environmental protections under the ‘cauldron principle,’ scapegoating bats, newts, snails and spiders to fast-track housing. Ministers—from Starmer to Reeves—have overridden conditions (e.g. Sussex’s ramshorn snail and wetland safeguards), used emergency and Henry VIII powers, and outsourced conservation funding to developers. Major NGOs remain silent. Monbiot warns this full-spectrum assault risks irreplaceable habitats, legal rights (Aarhus), and public green spaces, and calls on nature lovers to fight back.

articles.title: AI might be creating a ‘permanent underclass’ but it’s the makers of the tech bubble who are replaceable | Van Badham
articles.trailText: Despite the relentless insistence of tech’s grifters, AI is not industrially inevitable – or even sustainable. Which is why it is time to push back
articles.summary: Van Badham argues that runaway AI hype threatens to create a “permanent underclass” by displacing workers once systems surpass human capacity—yet AI’s economics and sustainability are deeply flawed. Skyrocketing energy, water use and three-year hardware lifespans, plus 95% of pilots yielding no ROI and bubble warnings from the Bank of England, expose overconfidence. Historical wins—in Japanese auto plants, Australian nursing and the 2023 Writers Guild strike—show unions can secure job guarantees and retraining. Collective bargaining, regulation and demanding paid data and labor rights, not techno-grift, are the antidote to AI’s backlash.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the China spy trial: an opportunity for Labour to prove it understands the threat from Beijing | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Dispelling confusion about the collapsed case would build confidence that the government has a coherent policy
articles.summary: Editorial: With China posing both strategic risks and economic opportunities through its mineral resource dominance and supply-chain power, the collapse of a high-profile espionage case against a parliamentary researcher and a teacher—dropped by the CPS for failing to explicitly name Beijing as a threat under the Official Secrets Act—has laid bare Labour’s awkward diplomacy. Accusations from Conservatives, led by Kemi Badenoch, of a government cover-up collide with Starmer’s pledge to publish witness statements. The piece urges early transparency to define a coherent UK-China policy that balances trade engagement and national security.

articles.title: A leaked memo, a Maga-style hat and a trail of broken pledges – it’s Labour’s great housing betrayal | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: Ignore the bombast: Steve ‘build, baby, build’ Reed’s boast looks likely to end in targets more pathetic than they are now, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Aditya Chakrabortty reveals how Labour housing secretary Steve Reed’s Trumpian “Build, Baby, Build” stunt masks a leaked memo proposing to slash London’s affordable-housing threshold from 35% to 20%, fund half via public money, suspend developer levies and fast-track schemes already beset by one in six freezes. Big builders (Barratt, Vistry, Berkeley) were briefed; councils and tenant groups excluded. With just 3,248 of 88,000 homes started and the 1.5m-home pledge unravelling, up to 20,000 affordable units could vanish, worsening a crisis that leaves 73,000 households in temporary flats and 13,000 rough sleepers.

articles.title: The Guardian view on EU accession for Ukraine: Orbán must not be allowed to call the tune | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: In a critical phase, Brussels should find a way to bypass Hungary’s prime minister in the interests of European solidarity
articles.summary: In this editorial, The Guardian warns that Viktor Orbán’s sustained veto of Ukraine and Moldova’s EU accession jeopardizes European solidarity amid heightened security challenges from Russia and an unreliable US ally. It urges Brussels to bypass Hungary’s blockade—either by adopting qualified-majority voting or sidestepping formal approval at each accession phase—thus allowing Kyiv and Chişinău to advance reforms and morale. With Orbán weaponizing his veto ahead of elections, the EU must innovate to secure its strategic future.

articles.title: Trump hates this ‘super bad’ photo of him in Time magazine. I almost feel sympathy … almost | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: This is a man who once mocked the movements of a disabled reporter, so we’ll take what schadenfreude we can get, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Brockes highlights Donald Trump’s fixation on an unflattering Time magazine cover photo—shot from below to accentuate his “turkey wattle” neck and tiny “crown”—despite its effusive “His Triumph” headline. His Truth Social rant calling it “super bad” revealed his vanity. Brockes contends the image was a deliberate troll by Time, using a “hit photo” to undercut him. She likens this low-blow tactic to other celeb photo attacks—like those on Olivia Colman—where unflattering angles sting more than words.

articles.title: I went to Marina Abramović’s erotic, explicit new art show – and there was an awful lot to take in | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: The ‘grandmother of performance art’ and I both have Slavic roots. But I didn’t recognise any of her 14th-century Dalmatian fertility rites – and neither did my mum, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Adrian Chiles attends Marina Abramović’s Balkan Erotic Epic at Manchester’s Aviva Studios, a sprawling 13-act performance piece revisiting Slavic fertility rites and sexuality. Opening with a Tito funeral procession, it unfolds simultaneously on multiple stages: men humping fields, women exposing themselves to sky and earth, naked dancers with skeletons, a stony café tableau of Tito’s widow, and folk-tale narrations of fish-insertion love potions and wedding-night bridge rituals. Explicit, ambitious and rooted in 14th-century Dalmatian lore, it’s an immersive, challenging magnum opus that rewards curiosity but demands a strong stomach.

articles.title: Pete Hegseth’s attempt to gag journalism is a resounding failure | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: Hegseth wants journalists to only publish ‘explicitly authorized’ information. That is not how the free press works
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Margaret Sullivan criticizes defense chief Pete Hegseth’s new Pentagon policy requiring reporters to sign agreements to publish only “explicitly authorized” information. Drawing on NPR’s Tom Bowman’s experience revealing hidden complications in the 2003 Iraq invasion, Sullivan shows how major outlets—The Guardian, AP, NYT, Reuters, Politico, WaPo, the Atlantic and even Fox—have refused to comply, while OANN alone agreed. She and former AP editor Dan Perry warn the policy transforms journalists from watchdogs into state functionaries, undermines First Amendment protections and risks labeling reporters security threats. Journalists will continue to pursue coverage through leaks, FOI petitions and other legal means.

articles.title: Where do babies come from? Robert F Kennedy Jr doesn’t seem to know | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Science tells us that foetuses develop in the uterus, rather than the placenta – but the US health secretary has a different take. Why are Republicans so clueless about women’s bodies, asks Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi skewers US health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr’s gaffe after he claimed pregnant women “gobble Tylenol with their baby in the placenta,” revealing his ignorance of basic fetal biology. She notes his anti-vaccine stance and unfounded link between acetaminophen and autism, then catalogs a string of Republican male lawmakers’ medical blunders—from Alabama’s abortion ban based on mysterious “chromosome” timing, Ohio’s impossible ectopic pregnancy reimplantation proposal, Idaho’s camera-swallowing idea, to Todd Akin’s rape myths—to illustrate widespread GOP cluelessness about women’s bodies.

articles.title: A lasting peace between Israel and Palestine? We’ve heard that before – the result was more bloodshed | Jason Burke
articles.trailText: In 1982, Ronald Reagan picked up the phone to Menachem Begin to tell him to end a war. There are lessons from history and we need to learn them, says Guardian international security correspondent Jason Burke
articles.summary: In 1982 Reagan, appalled by images of injured children, forced Menachem Begin to end Israel’s siege of Beirut, disarm the PLO and agree to a US peacekeeping force. After its withdrawal, a Lebanese proxy’s assassination triggered Maronite massacres in Palestinian camps, Hizbollah’s rise and collapse of secular factions that fueled religious militancy. Burke warns that Trump’s similar 20-point Gaza ceasefire push and Western disregard for Palestinian legitimacy and root causes echo 1982’s failures, risking history repeating with deadly consequences.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch wants to end ‘rip-off degrees’ – but I wouldn’t have created Horrid Henry without mine | Francesca Simon
articles.trailText: I studied Old and Middle English. Although I didn’t know it, I couldn’t have chosen a better subject to train me to become a children’s author, says author Francesca Simon
articles.summary: Children’s author Francesca Simon rebuts Kemi Badenoch’s bid to scrap “rip-off” humanities degrees, arguing her Old and Middle English studies at Yale and Oxford shaped Horrid Henry’s alliterative style, character humour theory and narrative rhythms—skills vital for young readers. She cites the creative industries’ £125 bn value and 2.4 million jobs to underscore arts’ economic and cultural worth, stresses critical thinking and research as unpredictable yet essential career assets, and urges studying subjects one loves rather than measuring education solely by immediate earnings.

articles.title: The crisis engulfing Emmanuel Macron contains a warning for Keir Starmer | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: The French president dominated the centre ground but has failed to build a legacy there. Labour is in danger of doing the same, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Rafael Behr argues that Emmanuel Macron’s decision to dissolve France’s assembly last summer backfired, empowering the far-left and far-right and triggering months of parliamentary paralysis. His overconfidence, failure to build broader alliances and reluctance to heed electoral arithmetic have left his presidency leg-shy and vulnerable. Behr warns Keir Starmer that Britain’s Labour could repeat Macron’s error: captured centre-ground mandates without durable coalitions risk isolation and empower populists, producing frenetic disorder with no lasting reform or legacy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the IMF’s warning: Britain’s economy runs hot for profits, cold for pay | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Labour is misreading the economics – leaving it unable to deal with the G7’s worst inflation and flat living standard
articles.summary: IMF warns UK faces G7’s highest inflation and flat living standards: real wages stagnant 11 months, unemployment up to 4.8%. JRF forecasts a 1.3% drop in disposable incomes by 2029, the steepest since 1961. Editorial argues inflation is driven by profit mark-ups, not excess demand, and highlights rising household caution despite high saving rates. It calls for a larger deficit to offset the trade gap, higher benefits, better-funded public services, and price caps on energy, housing and transport. Labour is urged to shift from asset-focused growth to wealth taxes and redistributive measures to lift pay and living standards.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the rising risk from flooding: uninsurable buildings should focus minds on climate adaptation | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The bleak future faced by one small town offers a cautionary tale about the threat from global heating
articles.summary: In Tenbury Wells, seven floods in four years have left three council-owned buildings uninsurable after £30m defence plans were shelved, mirroring wider trends: UK weather claims hit £585m in 2024 and flood-risk properties may rise from 6.3m to 8m by 2050. Despite underfunded defences below the £1.5bn needed, ministers prioritise natural flood management, while Tory proposals to scrap the Climate Change Act signal retreat on resilience. The town’s plight exemplifies the urgent need for climate adaptation policies, adequate infrastructure investment and insurer-driven pressure to mitigate escalating flood threats.

articles.title: Trump’s role in halting Gaza’s suffering was driven by self-interest. Will that be enough for him to finish the job? | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: The US president’s Gulf allies and supporters at home might just persuade him to pursue lasting peace. And then there’s always next year’s Nobel prize, says writer and academic Kenneth Roth
articles.summary: Kenneth Roth credits Trump for halting US support for Israel’s Gaza offensive and coercing Netanyahu into a 20-point plan driven by his evangelical base and Gulf allies’ pressure. Yet the pause risks collapse: Netanyahu hasn’t renounced resuming war if Hamas remains armed, and Trump offers no timeline for Palestinian statehood beyond vague PA reform. Gulf states insist on a clear path to two states before funding Gaza’s reconstruction. Roth warns continued international and regional pressure is vital to secure lasting peace—and perhaps Trump’s coveted Nobel prize.

articles.title: I chaired the US Federal Election Commission. Now there’s no cop on the beat | Ellen L Weintraub
articles.trailText: Democracy is under attack – and the watchdog agency has no quorum. It must be restored
articles.summary: Former FEC chair Ellen Weintraub warns that under Trump the agency overseeing campaign finance has been crippled, lacking a quorum after two commissioners resigned. Meanwhile Trump’s DOJ is pursuing unproven voter-fraud claims, disbanding the foreign interference unit, and making registration harder. He’s even threatened military intervention in Democratic areas. With the FEC unable to enforce disclosure rules or curb dark money, billionaire donors face no checks as 2026 looms. Rebuilding a functional commission is essential to uphold transparency, limit abuses of power, and protect American democracy from unchecked political spending.

articles.title: Pregnancy skincare products target women at a vulnerable time. Do any work or do they just stretch the truth? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: Oils, creams and lotions with names like ‘mummy’s tummy’, ‘bump love’ and ‘belly butter’ abound
articles.summary: Targeted pregnancy skincare brands hawk oils and creams claiming to prevent stretch marks, boost elasticity or soothe skin—often with gimmicky names like “bump love” yet use basic ingredients (sunflower oil) and cost $68–75. Dermatologists say genetics, age and rate of weight gain drive stretch marks; topicals only hydrate the surface and lack evidence for prevention. For existing marks, time fades redness; vascular lasers or topical retinoids (postpartum) can modestly improve appearance. Safe pregnancy skincare: simple, fragrance-free moisturisers with glycerin and ceramides; avoid retinoids, hydroquinone and high-dose salicylic acid.

articles.title: Good news: men have stopped disrupting women’s sport with dildos. Bad news: now they’re betting on their periods | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Speculating on basketball players’ menstrual cycles is creepy and intrusive. In other words, it’s just what you’d expect when women must be punished for standing out, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi outlines a shift in misogynistic stunts: after neon-green dildo tossings at WNBA games by crypto memecoin promoters—now waning following arrests—gamblers have turned to 'period betting,' guessing players' menstrual cycles to predict performance. Influencers like @fademebets rely on flimsy cues (injury reports, soreness) despite privacy and hacking risks. While research confirms hormonal effects on athletic output, Mahdawi warns this creepy intrusion underscores persistent sexism, even as women's sports surge in popularity and fight for funding and respect.

articles.title: Compare Donald Trump with Kissinger and you’ll be lost. But Taylor Swift? That’s more like it | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: As he conducts the symphony of applause for his peace deal, the key to understanding him is this: he’s not a politician, not even close – he’s a star, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde argues that Donald Trump’s Egypt peace deal was less a diplomatic breakthrough than a megastar’s launch event. Trump behaves like a showbiz phenom—obsessed with ratings, branding and spectacle—turning every initiative into a ‘Donald Trump vehicle’ and subsuming collaborators’ work into his ego. Comparisons to Kissinger miss the point; Hyde says he’s better understood alongside pop icons like Taylor Swift, driven by commerce, self-promotion and staged authenticity rather than political doctrine.

articles.title: Be sure of this: many of the horrors the west allowed in Gaza will come closer to home | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: History shows the crimes of empire were later mirrored on European soil. Dehumanisation and militarised terror both seem normalised now, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Owen Jones warns that the West’s facilitation of Israel’s genocidal assault on Gaza—underpinned by extreme dehumanization, mass killings, torture and the testing of weapons and surveillance technologies on Palestinians—echoes colonial brutality that historically returned to Europe as fascism. He shows how Western governments and media have normalized these horrors and demonized dissent at home. Now Europe’s far-right parties celebrate Israel’s ethno-state model and security playbook, he cautions, threatening to deploy the same militarized terror and dystopian technologies against Western populations.

articles.title: Life in Gaza may go from utter hell to mere nightmare. What happens now? | Hussein Agha and Robert Malley
articles.trailText: It took an American president unbound by traditional domestic constraints to get this done and provide the parties with what they could accept
articles.summary: Trump’s Gaza peace plan imposes atonement on Palestinians for the 7 October atrocities but not on Israel for its retaliation. It prescribes Gaza deradicalization, micromanages Palestinian governance, ignores Israel’s occupation, and lacks timetables or enforcement. Backed by Erdoğan and Doha’s emir to guarantee Hamas, it secures hostage releases and aid but shifts Gazans from utter hell to a mere nightmare, leaving them twice-dispossessed refugees. Excluding official Palestinian leaders, it cements Israel’s military dominance, risks fueling radicalization, and underscores that only unorthodox power politics—not technical blueprints—can reshape a more durable truce.

articles.title: Soaring bills are the gift that keeps on giving for Reform. Shame Labour doesn’t have the guts to do anything about them | Mathew Lawrence
articles.trailText: A cost of living crisis is not inevitable if there is the will to stop companies extracting profits from Britain’s essential services, says Mathew Lawrence of the Common Wealth thinktank
articles.summary: Mathew Lawrence argues Britain’s cost of living crisis stems from profit-driven privatisation of essential services—energy firms skimmed about 25% of household bills, water companies divert nearly a third to dividends. He warns right-wing Reform UK exploits soaring bills to scapegoat migrants, and Labour’s inaction risks ceding ground. This “privatisation premium” siphons billions from households, acts like an unvoted poll tax that hits lower-income families hardest and inflates CPI. He urges public ownership of water, energy, and transport—citing Greater Manchester’s Bee Network’s 15% fare cut—to boost incomes, curb inflation, and enable progressive taxation.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves, just tell voters why taxes must go up – and then do it | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The Thatcherite notion of tax as wicked must be challenged in the upcoming budget. Target unearned wealth; explain that tax creates a decent society, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues Chancellor Rachel Reeves should seize November’s budget to explain why tax rises are essential for a decent society. Facing a £40bn shortfall, Toynbee urges shedding Thatcherite ‘tax-phobia’ by targeting unearned property and capital gains wealth, closing relief loopholes, and equalising income tax and national insurance for pensioners, landlords and shareholders. Backed by IFS and Resolution Foundation, she endorses a 2p income-tax rise offset by NI cuts to protect workers, fund hospitals, schools, infrastructure and address the intergenerational wealth gap born of austerity and private boom.

articles.title: ‘Did two Brits spy for China?’ is one question. ‘Can any UK PM really stand up to China?’ is an even bigger one | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: It’s Keir Starmer’s turn to muddle through a problem that none of his predecessors solved: can his cash-poor nation afford to offend a superpower?, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff examines the aborted trial of Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry, accused of spying for China, and unpacks why the case fell apart once China wasn’t formally designated a national security threat. She highlights Westminster infighting over the role of veteran adviser Jonathan Powell, explores how past governments courted Chinese investment while grappling with espionage risks, and argues that Keir Starmer faces a herculean choice: stand up to a cash-rich superpower or risk Britain’s economic recovery and security.

articles.title: France's political upheaval isn't temporary - it's a profound constitutional crisis | Pierre Purseigle
articles.trailText: The old prime minister is back with a new team, but it can’t last: a democracy can’t have a president with the powers of a king, says French historian Pierre Purseigle
articles.summary: Historian Pierre Purseigle argues France faces a systemic, not transient, crisis as Macron’s hyper-presidential Fifth Republic grinds to a halt amid a hung parliament, fiscal strain and international turmoil. After dissolving parliament post-EU elections, Macron reconvened Sébastien Lecornu as prime minister for a minority cabinet incapable of winning a budget or commanding assembly support. Macron rebuffed coalition-building, appointing sequential weak minority governments and risking fresh elections. His top-down, technocratic style, supply-side economics and disdain for civil society fueled gilets jaunes unrest and exacerbated public alienation. Rooted in de Gaulle’s quasi-monarchic vision, the regime’s structural flaws now threaten its survival.

articles.title: Watching from Australia while Donald Trump targets my home of Chicago with armed troops prompts deep questions | Miles Herbert
articles.trailText: I never again want to have to look back and wonder, could I have done more?
articles.summary: From Australia, audio producer Miles Herbert confronts haunting footage of armed men in Chicago after Trump’s bid to federalize the National Guard and ramp up ICE enforcement. Though assured his family is safe, he wonders if he could have done more to resist rising authoritarianism, drawing parallels with El Salvador deportations. He lauds US journalists’ front-line coverage and warns that Australia—amid One Nation gains, anti-immigration rallies and Nazi marches—is not immune. Quoting fascism expert Jason Stanley on Australia’s vulnerability and Ta-Nehisi Coates’ charge for writers to “save the world,” he urges active defence of democracy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on peace in Gaza: the relief is real, but Trump’s promise of a ‘golden age’ rings hollow | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Hostage and prisoner releases are bringing joy to families. But there is no guarantee that the ceasefire will end Palestinian suffering
articles.summary: Following a ceasefire in Gaza, the release of Israeli hostages and 2,000 Palestinian detainees brought relief amid mixed emotions. Donald Trump brokered the deal at Sharm el-Sheikh, yet his plan lacks a clear path to Palestinian statehood, risks Gaza-West Bank division and freezes Palestinian agency. While humanitarian aid and rebuilding are crucial, vague proposals for an international stabilisation force and no timeline for self-determination mean this reprieve offers no guarantees of lasting peace.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the online scam industry: authorities must not forget that perpetrators are often victims too | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A lucrative sector is spreading fast as criminal enterprises force abused and trafficked workers to cheat others
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial highlights the twofold human cost of the multibillion-dollar online scam industry: consumers bilked by “pig-butchering” frauds and trafficked workers forced into modern-slavery cybercrime compounds. Research shows over 200,000 people coerced into operations across Southeast Asia and beyond, enduring torture, debt bondage, and constant surveillance. Criminal syndicates leverage satellite internet, deepfake technology and corrupt officials to evade crackdowns and shift locations. The piece calls for international intelligence sharing, tech-platform accountability, strengthened civil society partnerships, and crucially, protection for coerced scammers from prosecution.

articles.title: The Conservative party’s obsession with Margaret Thatcher merch feels less kitsch and more cult | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: On the former prime minister’s centenary, celebratory tat has included branded Toby jugs and whisky, while her old clothes were on display at conference. Is this really what the Iron Lady would have wanted, asks Zoe Williams
articles.summary: On Margaret Thatcher’s centenary, Zoe Williams critiques the Conservative party’s shift from playful nostalgia to cultish reverence. She describes Warhol-style portraits hanging in party HQ, branded Toby jugs and whisky, glass-cased outfits and cardboard cutouts at conference, plus a fan-made mosaic. References to leadership contenders dressing as Thatcher or invoking her image feel less tribute than a faith-like project to relive 1979. Williams argues this obsessive merchandising and shrine culture betray Thatcher’s pragmatic legacy and questions whether the Iron Lady would have endorsed such devotion.

articles.title: Here’s what you need to know about Starmer’s illiberal protest curbs: they would have killed the Labour party at birth | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: The rights we enjoy in the UK, and the movement the PM purports to lead, were built on protest. Those rights are in dire peril, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot argues that Keir Starmer’s Labour government is pursuing illiberal curbs on protest that, if applied historically, would have outlawed the 19th-century labour movement—Scotland’s uprisings, Merthyr and Newport risings, the Swing riots and the 1842 general strike—that gave birth to the party. He chronicles decades of legislation (Public Order Act 1986, Trade Union Act 1992, Criminal Justice Act 1994, Terrorism Act 2000, SOCPA 2005, Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Act 2022, Public Order Act 2023) that stifle assembly and dissent. Monbiot highlights recent measures labeling Palestine Action as “terrorist,” banning protests near places of worship and on grounds of “cumulative impact,” and warns these erosions of free expression risk authoritarianism and undermine democracy.
