articles.summary: Sudan’s Darfur city of El Fasher has endured a 500-day RSF siege, leaving 260,000 civilians facing starvation, airstrikes or flight to sexual violence. With 150,000 killed, 12 million displaced and 25 million in acute hunger, the world’s largest humanitarian crisis has been eclipsed by Ukraine and Gaza. US, Saudi, Egypt and UAE propose a truce to allow aid, while AU, EU and UK urge talks, yet SAF and RSF remain unwilling to compromise. External support from Egypt, Saudi and likely UAE fuels the conflict. The US accuses RSF of genocide; both sides face war crimes charges and SAF is accused of using chemical weapons.

articles.title: I’ve seen despair at the Labour conference, but Starmer’s battle for Britain’s soul is one he can still win | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The government’s fall in popularity has affected party morale, but there are signs that taking the fight to Farage can provide a much-needed spark, asks Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: At Labour’s autumn conference MPs and councillors expressed panic over the party’s rapid polling slump and fear of heavy local election losses, but Keir Starmer’s decision to directly challenge Reform UK and Nigel Farage’s hardline immigration agenda injected new energy. Rachel Reeves labelled Reform “the single greatest threat to living standards,” while Andy Burnham’s insurgent rhetoric on proportional representation rallied grassroots activists. Polling suggests Labour risks hemorrhaging left-wing voters more than Farage supporters, so strategists urge a focus on green investment, housing, and jobs to reclaim public trust ahead of 2025.

articles.title: Labour just doesn’t get it: workers feel poorer than ever. Is it any wonder Reform is rising? | Sharon Graham
articles.trailText: Until the government starts tacking in a radically new direction, it will continue crashing in the polls. It could – and must – act differently, says Sharon Graham, general secretary of Unite
articles.summary: Sharon Graham of Unite argues Labour under Starmer ignores worker decline: wages stagnated post-2008 crash, austerity slashed public spending 2010–19 and hollowed out services, while essential staff remain underpaid amid a cost-of-living crisis. Food prices are up 38% since 2021, energy bills 44% higher, even as Tesco and energy giants post record profits. Labour’s muted spending rise and obsession with fiscal targets exacerbate its polling slump. Unite proposes raising £50bn annually via a 1% wealth tax, aligning capital gains with income tax and extending NI to investments. Without bold public investment and tax reform, voters may turn to Reform UK, risking democratic stability.

articles.title: As my son prepares to graduate high school, I’m feeling nostalgic for the many parenting milestones I’ve bid farewell | Vivienne Pearson
articles.trailText: I’ve already been disavowed of my naive notions that this next parenting stage is entirely stress-free
articles.summary: As my youngest son nears high-school graduation, Vivienne Pearson reflects on saying goodbye to parenting milestones—from first kicks and smiles to unpredictable final moments like breastfeeding and hand-holding. This year marked the last parent-teacher interview, the last time inside the school gates, and the bittersweet graduation assembly slideshow. She’ll miss neither school lunches nor daily sickness texts, but anticipates new, uncharted stepping stones as her son faces exams, potential gap-year adventures and family-wide significance of this transition. Pearson embraces future “me time” while acknowledging the inevitable stress that follows even the most eagerly awaited milestones.

articles.title: My son is turning 18 – and I am inexplicably sad | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: He is now an adult, so I have no right to dictate the state of his hair or his choice of diet. But I hadn’t expected this to be such an emotional wrench, writes Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams chronicles how her son T’s 18th birthday—a milestone she’s witnessed and written about since his first hours—triggers unexpected sorrow as she confronts the end of her right to dictate his life. She reflects on writing about him, ethical boundaries, relinquishing control over his diet, appearance, friendships and stepping back from mum alliances. She even anticipates years of apologies for recounting his life in columns before he could consent. Wistfully, she resolves to honour his new adult autonomy by believing in his independence despite the emotional wrench of this symbolic watershed.

articles.title: Perhaps only civil servants and I believe it, but 'networking' is the stuff life is made of | Viv Groskop
articles.trailText: The Cabinet Office wants to ban ‘networking meetings’ in working hours. Call me an interfering Sir Humphrey, but isn’t actually talking to colleagues the way to get things done, asks comedian and author Viv Groskop
articles.summary: The Cabinet Office has barred civil servants from holding networking meetings during working hours, requiring after-hours scheduling and senior sign-off for events. While proponents argue this refocuses staff on core duties, critics – invoking Sir Humphrey Appleby – warn it’s patronising, risks morale and overlooks that informal chats build trust, alliances and efficiency. Against a backdrop of rocketing work-related stress, Viv Groskop argues that enforced isolation hampers collaboration and suggests the ban might inadvertently revive networking as a rebellious, vital practice.

articles.title: The abortion pill is safe. But why should Trump let facts get in the way of his agenda?  | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: RFK Jr is conducting a review of mifepristone, citing a deeply flawed study. The move could be devastating for women
articles.summary: RFK Jr’s HHS is reevaluating 25-year-old mifepristone approvals based on a non–peer-reviewed Ethics & Public Policy Center report that conflates normal bleeding with hemorrhage and inflates serious adverse events to ~11%, versus under 0.5% in peer-reviewed meta-analyses showing >99% no complications. The Trump administration, under anti-choice pressure, has barred Medicaid funding for abortion clinics, spread junk science on Tylenol-autism, and joined GOP-led lawsuits in Missouri, Idaho and Kansas to roll back FDA telemedicine and mail-order access—threatening safe, at-home abortion and potentially reviving dangerous illegal procedures.

articles.title: £6.50 for a coffee? I’m going back to instant | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: It’s not just prices that are out of control – I can’t take the way fans talk about their favourite brew, or my own coffee machine’s reluctance to just do its job, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington laments skyrocketing latte art culture and £6.50 coffees with DNA-sequencing-level kit and artisanal rituals invading York and home kitchens. Her high-maintenance bean-to-cup machine feels more troll than appliance—triggering drip-tray riddles—and she’s sworn off acidic “fruity” brews. Citing Robert Pattinson’s GQ confession that he savors instant coffee’s oily sediment, she returns to powdered granules. Her first cup evokes acrid school-room nostalgia, but the second tastes satisfactory, freeing her from caffeine couture. She concludes minimalist instant delivers more happiness than over-engineered espresso theatrics.

articles.title: Russia’s provocations are menacing Nato. The cold war shows how it needs to respond | Sergey Radchenko
articles.trailText: Despite the cost of shooting down fighter jets and drones, small skirmishes remind both sides of the dangers of escalation, says academic Sergey Radchenko
articles.summary: Academic Sergey Radchenko warns that recent brazen Russian airspace incursions—drones over Poland and Romania, MiG-31s into Estonia—echo Cold War skirmishes. Historical shootdowns (U-2s, EC-121s, Korean and Black Sea incidents) show that downing intruders reinforces red lines without triggering major escalation. NATO should invoke Cold War protocols: ready to intercept and, if needed, shoot down violators to deter further provocations while sustaining quiet military-to-military and diplomatic channels. Europe, assuming a larger defense role amid US strategic drawdown, must couple firm force with behind-the-scenes dialogue to contain Putin’s tests.

articles.title: A friend’s advice to cut my tortured prose unlocked my career as a novelist | Andrew Martin
articles.trailText: What he said was simple, but it achieved a kind of sorcery. For the first time, my dream of becoming a writer seemed possible, says novelist Andrew Martin
articles.summary: In 1984, history student Andrew Martin discovered that his friend’s single-word advice—‘cut’—could strip away tangled phrasing and unlock clarity. After decluttering an overlong job application, he applied that principle to early stories, red-pen edits during pub evenings and, later, an Amstrad word processor. Pruning tired phrases and trusting materials would survive the edits, Martin found his authorial voice, overcame repeated rejections and ultimately published his first novel. He credits his still-languid, privately educated friend’s confidence in self-editing for sparking his career as a novelist.

articles.title: Kamala Harris’s election memoir shows just how deluded the Democrats still are | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: This unapologetic trawl through a doomed campaign reveals a celebrity-obsessed party high on its own supply. It would be hilarious if it wasn’t so tragic, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Nesrine Malik dissects Kamala Harris’s memoir 107 Days, arguing it exposes a Democratic Party high on celebrity spectacle and lacking substance. Over 107 days on the trail, she prioritized celebrity rosters and viral moments yet offered no coherent vision or values-driven leadership. Harris emerges as self-absorbed and vague, banking on name recognition and media praise rather than distinct policy, from Gaza to economic reform. Malik highlights her failure to build credible coalitions or diverge meaningfully from Biden, preferring optics over conviction. The result is a farcical campaign that underscores Harris’s self-delusion and the party’s incapacity to challenge Trump.

articles.title: German identity doesn’t rely on cars – Brussels should face down the mighty automakers | Tania Roettger
articles.trailText: Mercedes-Benz and other big manufacturers want to overturn the EU’s 2035 ban on petrol cars. This would be as disastrous for jobs as for the climate, says Berlin-based journalist Tania Roettger
articles.summary: German manufacturers, led by Mercedes-Benz, are lobbying the European Commission to reverse or dilute its 2035 ban on new CO2-emitting cars and relax interim EV quotas, warning of job losses and infeasibility. Brussels considers hybrid exceptions. Critics argue rolling back targets would undermine climate goals, weaken Germany’s global competitiveness—already trailing Tesla and Chinese rivals—and jeopardize a sector that shed 50,000 jobs in 2024. Chancellor Merz sided with automakers’ call for “technology neutrality,” but Ursula von der Leyen and 150 EV companies urge adherence to the 2035 phase-out to ensure regulatory stability and accelerate electrification.

articles.title: The Guardian view on AI and jobs: the tech revolution should be for the many not the few | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Britain risks devolving its digital destiny to Silicon Valley. As a TUC manifesto argues, those affected must have a greater say in shaping the workplace of the future
articles.summary: Guardian editorial warns UK risks ceding its digital destiny to Silicon Valley as generative AI threatens creative and white-collar jobs, squeezes entry-level roles and incurs hidden environmental costs. Echoing EP Thompson’s defense of early Luddites, it criticises a laissez-faire rollout prioritising shareholder profit over workers’ rights and public interest. New polling shows Britons view AI as an economic risk. The TUC’s ‘worker-first’ AI strategy calls for employee input on tech deployment. The piece urges Labour and state investment to manage AI for the common good, beginning in the workplace.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the 2025 Booker prize: bringing posh bingo to the BookTok generation | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: With this year’s shortlist announced live to the public, Britain’s most prestigious literary award is finding ways to engage new audiences
articles.summary: The Booker Prize, historically elite “posh bingo,” is modernizing by livestreaming its shortlist announcement with interactive chat, targeting the BookTok generation. This year’s varied shortlist includes works by former winners (Kiran Desai’s The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny, David Szalay’s Flesh, Andrew Miller’s The Land in Winter) and authors such as Ben Markovits, Susan Choi and Katie Kitamura. Though no debuts are shortlisted, the new Hilary Mantel prize and a Bookstagram award spotlight emerging writers. With a booming TikTok following and digital book club, the Booker balances prestige and popular engagement, reaffirming fiction’s communal power amid cultural shifts.

articles.title: Racist voices are becoming louder and moving into the mainstream. How can I help my client feel safe? | Ahona Guha
articles.trailText: Within the context of increasing anti-migrant and anti-Muslim rhetoric, Aisha found that she was hypervigilant and anxious about the possibility of another assault
articles.summary: Amid rising far-right anti-migrant and anti-Muslim rhetoric, clinical psychologist Dr Ahona Guha details culturally attuned therapy for Aisha, a Pakistani-Australian nurse haunted by a past racially charged assault and daily microaggressions at work. Guha underscores validating structural racism rather than quick reframing, using EMDR to reduce trauma-driven hypervigilance and TMJ, plus lifestyle stabilization and interpersonal effectiveness training. By externalizing prejudice as the perpetrators’ fault and building assertiveness, Aisha gains empowerment and a greater sense of safety in a hostile environment.

articles.title: We Americans love remaking British TV. Must the UK remake our odious politicians? | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: A recent trip to Britain from my native California presented some worrying truths about our shared political future
articles.summary: Dave Schilling, a Californian comedy writer, visits the UK and contrasts his lifelong obsession with bleak, witty British TV with the current political landscape. He sees Nigel Farage as a less theatrical Trump and notes UK media’s relative disinterest in his antics. Schilling savors dry cultural staples like Good Morning Britain and pub newspapers, tours the Tate Modern and Barbican, and reflects on shared American–British nihilism fueling populism, arguing both nations crave a dose of optimistic razzle-dazzle.

articles.title: Tech bros want women to have more babies. But they’re going about it the wrong way | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Dropping birthrates are worrying Elon Musk, JD Vance and the like. But their proposed remedies are risible. Here are some surefire winners, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington skewers Silicon Valley pronatalists like Musk and Vance for offering token cash incentives as birthrates fall amid ecological, political and childcare crises. She proposes seven bolder, ranked interventions: a ‘birth-row’ gourmet meal, an upgraded baby-box with streaming and Mehldrives, legal contracts to enforce non-birthing parents’ mental-load duties, a no-questions life-leave week, genetically ‘cuter’ infants, accelerated newborn independence and radically ‘disrupted’ birthing tech (egg-laying or pouch delivery), plus universal childcare and psychosocial support.

articles.title: On a trip to Kent, I saw how politics is being shaped by the west’s growing hostility to outsiders | John Harris
articles.trailText: With a Reform council, small boat arrivals and asylum seeker accommodation, this county lays bare an increasingly divided Britain, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris visits Kent to reveal deepening anti-immigrant politics: at Folkestone’s Napier barracks, asylum seekers live in military surplus behind fences next to new-build estates. He tracks Reform UK’s local surge, shaping council policy on migrants, digital ID proposals and punitive housing. Encounters with hostile “boat watchers” and far-right protests highlight rural England’s polarization. A refugee nurse’s fear of growing xenophobia underscores how Britain’s public discourse has shifted towards exclusion and punitive deterrence.

articles.title: The US government is facing a crisis of legitimacy | Daniel Mendiola
articles.trailText: As the constitutional order frays, the US could look to Brazil as a demonstration of a functioning democracy
articles.summary: Daniel Mendiola argues that the Trump administration's anti-immigrant zeal, civil rights rollbacks and repeated defiance of courts have shredded the US social contract, provoking a crisis of legitimacy. He details abuses—from spurious deportations and a paid El Salvador prison scheme to a Supreme Court that blocks injunctions and grants executive immunity. Contrasted with Brazil’s prosecution of Bolsonaro for coup attempts, US institutions falter. Mendiola urges peaceful civic action, especially fearless student and academic protests, to restore constitutional limits and reaffirm democratic legitimacy.

articles.title: Trump and Putin are threatening to carve up Europe between them. Suddenly, it all feels a bit 1939 | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: Forget the US president’s seeming volte-face on Ukraine this week: he and Putin fundamentally agree that European liberal democracy is the problem, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Guardian commentator Simon Tisdall warns that Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin, echoing Hitler and Stalin in 1939, are co-operating to weaken European liberal democracy. Though no formal pact exists, both share an ultranationalist, anti-EU agenda, deploying political interference, economic coercion, hybrid warfare and culture-war tactics. Trump’s erratic Ukraine policy masks ideological subversion and toothless sanctions; Putin steps up cyber-attacks, military threats and support for pro-Moscow populists. Their parallel pincer movement—tariffs, disinformation, covert sabotage and backing of hard-right parties—threatens Europe’s security, unity and progressive values.

articles.title: Autistic people could teach Donald Trump a thing or two about focus, facts and empathy | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: While not without its challenges, autism isn’t a curse to be cured of, as the likes of the President and RFK Jr want us to believe, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett rebuts Donald Trump and RFK Jr’s portrayal of autism as a disease needing a cure and challenges the administration’s claims linking prenatal acetaminophen to autism. She highlights autistic strengths—hyperfocus on subjects like the Roman empire, strict adherence to facts versus Trump’s thousands of falsehoods, profound empathy driving solidarity with causes such as Palestine, exceptional memory for timetables and scripts, pure joy expressed through stimming, and authentic love exemplified by her brother’s simple Gestalt phrase—arguing these traits surpass chaotic political rhetoric.

articles.title: What would you do if a supermarket accidentally gave you £300 of groceries you hadn’t paid for? | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: The law says you should try to return them. But be honest – wouldn’t you be tempted to keep them?
articles.summary: A Mumsnet user who cancelled a Tesco order and got a refund still received £300 of groceries, sparking a debate. Some argued a giant retailer won’t miss £300 and keeping the haul is tempting amid the cost-of-living crisis; others likened it to shoplifting and stressed honesty. Under the 2013 Consumer Contracts Regulations, unsolicited goods legally remain the trader’s property and must be returned. The author shares a duplicate rug anecdote: she phoned customer service despite the lure of free profit, reflecting on integrity, karma and whether such windfalls test character or offer consequence-free gains.

articles.title: Trump’s war on Tylenol is also very much a war on women | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: A concern for women’s health is absolutely not at the heart of it – rather, this is yet another way to control women
articles.summary: President Donald Trump, alongside Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., urged pregnant women to "tough it out" and avoid Tylenol, falsely linking prenatal acetaminophen exposure to autism despite no scientific evidence. Experts and even GOP figures like JD Vance warned against his baseless guidance, noting untreated fevers can harm fetuses and alternative painkillers carry their own risks. Critics decry his remarks as part of a broader misogynistic agenda—ignoring women’s pain, reinforcing mom-shaming culture, and exerting control over female bodies. Studies show women’s health concerns are often downplayed, while expectant fathers face far less scrutiny.

articles.title: Zuckerberg hailed AI ‘superintelligence’. Then his smart glasses failed on stage | Matthew Cantor
articles.trailText: The Meta CEO fumbled a demo of his AI Ray-Bans, giving us hope that the robots might be too dumb to take over
articles.summary: During Meta Connect 2025 in Menlo Park, Mark Zuckerberg endured multiple on-stage failures while showcasing the AI-powered Ray-Ban Meta Display glasses and a neural wristband interface. The glasses botched a video call with chef Jack Mancuso and dished odd cooking advice – misattributed to Wi-Fi – and the wristband repeatedly failed to dial colleague Andrew Bosworth. The floundering demos, echoing past high-profile AI blunders, drew awkward silence and a ‘Live demo – good luck’ banner. Critics argue this spectacle highlights tech’s willingness to shoehorn AI into gadgets that lack clear user demand, reviving skepticism about Silicon Valley’s innovation.

articles.title: Trump’s attack on George Soros is the next step in the autocrat’s handbook | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: Having already attacked judges, lawyers, media companies and universities, the president has set his sights on civil society
articles.summary: Kenneth Roth warns that Donald Trump, following an autocratic playbook, has directed DOJ prosecutors to investigate George Soros and his Open Society Foundations without evidence, aiming to undermine civil society and erode checks on presidential power. Paralleling Viktor Orbán’s scapegoating, Trump’s unsubstantiated claims of OSF funding violence traffick in “alternative facts” and McCarthyite smears. Roth notes Soros’s decades-long peaceful defense of free debate and predicts courts will reject any baseless prosecution, urging robust pushback to protect independent voices and the First Amendment. He highlights the administration’s reliance on biased Capital Research Center reports and baseless “domestic terrorism” allegations against OSF grantees, stressing that Soros’s philanthropic network defends human rights globally.

articles.title: Labour’s plan to revitalise high streets is good - now it has to make sure people hear about it | Morgan Jones
articles.trailText: There have been hyped policies before about local funding, but unlike ‘levelling up’ this project could lead to actual change, says Morgan Jones
articles.summary: Labour’s Pride in Place strategy, led by Steve Reed, earmarks targeted investment via deprivation and community needs indices to revitalise high streets, parks, shuttered facilities and shift power to residents through asset ownership rights. Framed as a robust alternative to Boris Johnson’s levelling-up, it embeds community empowerment through the English Devolution and Community Empowerment Bill. Aimed at rebuilding local trust and countering Reform UK’s anti-politics surge, success hinges on effective communication and lasting local autonomy.

articles.title: Most of gen Z watch TV with the subtitles on – and I understand why | Isabel Brooks
articles.trailText: Thanks to social media, we’re now living in a subtitled world - even when that means divided attentions and error-strewn captions, says freelance writer Isabel Brooks
articles.summary: Freelance writer Isabel Brooks examines why subtitles have become the default for Gen Z: surveys show up to 87% of young Britons now use captions more, driven by double-screening habits and social-media norms. Subtitles enable multitasking—read a line, check your phone, return before dialogue ends—but can spoil timing, mute acting nuance, and feature error-ridden AI transcripts. What began as accessibility has morphed into an algorithmic tool boosting reach on platforms like TikTok (where 85% of videos are watched muted). This shift reflects tech-infused consumption prioritising efficiency and comprehension over immersive viewing.

articles.title: Farewell, Amazon Fresh – the no tills thing was all a bit too awkward | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: The ‘just walk out’ innovation promised frictionless shopping – but these days, maybe we all need a bit less tech in our lives, says assistant newsletter editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Amazon Fresh’s experiment with “just walk out” AI-driven, till-free grocery stores in London—its 19 outlets—will close after failing to win over shoppers. Jason Okundaye found entry and exit procedures disorienting and panicky, likening pervasive sensors and computer vision to surveillance. Like unreliable self-scans and barrier scanners, it lacked human interaction, trust and the social rituals of shopping. It contrasts with Sainsbury’s scan-to-exit gates and Uniqlo self-service, which, though smooth, feel isolating. Okundaye says shoppers ultimately crave human contact and trust over frictionless tech.

articles.title: Israel’s ecocide in Gaza sends this message: even if we stopped dropping bombs, you couldn’t live here | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: Consider the annihilation of agricultural land alongside the genocide – and grasp the chilling totality of this attempt to eliminate all life, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot argues that Israel’s Gaza assault constitutes both genocide and intentional ecocide: bulldozers, herbicides and airstrikes have devastated 98.5% of arable land—greenhouses, orchards and olive trees razed to expand a security buffer. A crippling blockade, sewage collapse and chemical contamination ensure famine and environmental collapse. Bombing debris laced with toxic metals and white phosphorus adds lasting harm, while staggering war emissions foreclose recovery. Monbiot warns this “holocide” seeks to erase Palestinians and their homeland, breaching the Rome Statute.

articles.title: John Martinkus was a master of courageous, no-bullshit journalism. He shot from the hip | David Bridie
articles.trailText: He was a character straight out of a 1930s-set Coen brothers film. The big overcoat, pork pie hat, the low growl
articles.summary: John Martinkus (d. 14 Sep) was an award-nominated Australian foreign correspondent known for fearless, on-the-ground reporting in conflict zones. He broke early stories on pro-Jakarta militias in East Timor and gained clandestine access to West Papua, later exposing Iraq’s bogus WMD claims—famously calling reconstruction “the road to shit.” Kidnapped in 2004, he authored six books (including A Dirty Little War), taught journalism at the University of Tasmania, earned Timor-Leste’s independence medal and embodied old-school, no-bullshit war reporting.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour conference: a clash of visions and direction, not egos and personnel | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial : With his authority ebbing, Sir Keir Starmer offers continuity. Andy Burnham promises rupture. The choice is between Anglo-American orthodoxy and European-style interventionism
articles.summary: With Starmer’s authority waning amid poor polls and departures, Labour faces a choice between his market-led “abundance” vision—embracing Anglo-American supply-side liberalism, deregulation and a universal digital ID that risks a national data spine—and Andy Burnham’s “Manchesterism,” which calls for public control of housing, energy, transport, price regulation and borrowing £40bn for social stock. Burnham’s proposals echo European interventionist capitalism and revive Starmer’s abandoned Green New Deal pledges. Conference will decide whether Labour opts for cautious continuity or a rupture towards social investment and direct state action.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the 200th anniversary of the railways: much more than a way of getting from A to B | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial The bicentenary of the pioneering Stockton and Darlington line is a moment to celebrate a form of travel which shaped our culture
articles.summary: The Guardian marks the 200th anniversary of the Stockton and Darlington Railway, whose 1825 steam-powered Locomotion No 1 inaugural journey sparked social transformation beyond coal transport. Celebrations include a replica run, commemorative stamps and the revamped National Railway Museum. While Victorian railways reshaped leisure, commuting and regional identity, the modern network suffers under Beeching cuts, flawed privatisation and HS2 delays. The editorial calls for a public-driven strategic reboot to harness green growth and honour rail’s cultural legacy in literature, song and scenic routes.

articles.title: The case against digital ID cards: imagine how a Reform government could use them | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The civil liberties argument against giving the state more power over our lives becomes more urgent by the day – just look to Trump’s America, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff critiques Keir Starmer’s proposal for mandatory smartphone digital ID cards to curb illegal immigration, warning it echoes Theresa May’s hostile environment in your pocket. She argues such ID powers—combined with police facial-recognition—would create an invasive surveillance state, primed for misuse by a future Reform or Trump-style government. Hinsliff cautions these systems could enable mass deportations, crush protests, erode press freedoms, and be used to scrap the BBC licence fee, dilute online-harms laws and bypass parliamentary checks like the House of Lords, demanding robust civil-liberties safeguards before adoption.

articles.title: If Starmer wants to beat Reform, he’ll need more than ‘patriotic renewal’ – whatever that is | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Today’s big ‘fightback’ speech continued with the prime minister’s curious strategy of ceding ground to his enemies, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams critiques Starmer’s ‘fightback’ speech as vague, ceding ground to Reform UK. He calls for an ‘open fight’ against politics of division and proposes nebulous ‘patriotic renewal’, mandatory digital ID cards to curb illegal immigration, and green energy commitments. Williams argues that echoing Reform’s anti-migrant rhetoric undermines migrants and risks diluting Labour’s principles, warning that Starmer cannot defeat the hard right by mimicking its prejudices. She notes his green strategy—nuclear, wind and solar—reheated Green New Deal ideas, while his asylum and border stance panders to xenophobic sentiment, risking Labour’s credibility. Williams concludes that Starmer must distinguish himself rather than adopt hard-right tropes.

articles.title: To revive Labour, Starmer should go to conference with this pledge: we will clean politics of sleaze | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Another donations controversy, and another chance for the PM to draw the line – and stem the flow of dubious money into Westminster, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee argues Labour should seize the current donations row—over undisclosed staffing support from Labour Together—as a catalyst for Keir Starmer to pledge a sweeping clean-up of political finance. With public trust eroded by freebies scandals and “dark money” now accounting for one in ten donations, she calls for a £10,000 cap on all gifts, mandatory transparency of expat and corporate funds, and a shift to state funding to fill the shortfall. Models like Canada’s voter-allocated grants could ensure fairer, sleaze-free elections and revive faith in Westminster democracy.

articles.title: Trump has called the US postal service ‘a joke’. But don’t expect Amazon to replace it | Niamh Rowe
articles.trailText: Amid financial struggles and presidential criticism, USPS is facing challenges. But it plays an essential role in US life
articles.summary: Rowe traces the USPS from its 1775 founding to today’s $114 billion losses, persistent red ink driven by declining mail, rising costs and Trump’s 2020 dismissal of it as “a joke.” His administration floated agency dissolution, board shake-ups and an IPO, while Wells Fargo proposed carving off parcels—threatening small-town post offices, home delivery and vote-by-mail. A new $36 billion “Delivering for America” plan slows service in three-quarters of ZIP codes. Amazon’s $4 billion rural push expands to 13 000 ZIPs but cannot replace the USPS’s civic role.

articles.title: Will he? Won’t he? Do the King of the North’s antics remind you of anyone? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: As Andy Burnham heads to Liverpool, think back to the Tory conferences of 2017 and 2018. We all know how that panned out, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde critiques Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham’s self-styled ‘King of the North’ tour ahead of Labour’s Liverpool conference, suggesting his theatrical pre-title billing and anti-Westminster rhetoric echo Boris Johnson’s 2017-18 Tory conference power plays. Burnham has floated nationalisation and wealth taxes but offered no coherent platform, provoking scepticism from MPs—including Steve Reed—and insiders who doubt his capability. Hyde argues Britain’s chronic churn of ‘inadequate chancers’ isn’t cured by Burnham’s personality-driven bid, likening his hype to Paul Ince’s ‘big time Charlie’ gambit rather than serious leadership ambition.

articles.title: US marketing companies are helping to rebrand the genocide in Gaza | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Reports say PR teams are busy rewriting history in real time – not that the American media needs the help
articles.summary: US PR giants like Mark Penn’s Stagwell Global and SKDKnickerbocker are being paid by Israel’s foreign ministry to ‘rebrand’ its Gaza offensive as counter-terrorism, exploiting restricted media access, killed reporters and fear of “Radical Islam.” Using a $600k bot program and a “flood the zone” tactic, they amplify pro-Israel narratives and debunked atrocity claims to sow doubt and fatigue. Meanwhile US media owners (Paramount, TikTok bidders) and sympathetic politicians further shield these propaganda efforts, obscuring the genocide and delaying accountability.

articles.title: Our research makes it clear: by capitulating to the right, Labour is driving voters to Reform UK | Tarik Abou-Chadi and Stuart Turnbull-Dugarte
articles.trailText: Mimicking Farage on immigration is senseless. Labour voters feel betrayed; anti-immigration voters see through the ruse, say academics Tarik Abou-Chadi and Stuart Turnbull-Dugarte
articles.summary: Academic analysis of British Election Study data and 70+ Western European elections shows Labour’s rightward shift on immigration—including Starmer’s “island of strangers” speech and government white paper—has backfired. It alienates core progressives, fails to sway anti‐immigrant voters, and boosts Reform UK (Nigel Farage’s party) instead. Survey evidence finds tougher rhetoric declines Labour popularity, heightens immigration salience, but doesn’t convert Reform supporters. Similar patterns in Germany’s SPD under Olaf Scholz underscore how mainstream mimicry strengthens radical‐right parties. Progressive parties lose voters without gaining new ones and help normalize nativist discourse. Labour must abandon imitating the right to regain credibility.

articles.title: The TikTok deal puts even more media in the hands of the super-rich | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: Trump is clearing the way for US investors to control a wildly popular platform where millions get their news
articles.summary: As Trump expedites the sale of TikTok’s US operations to a consortium of billionaires (including Larry Ellison and Rupert Murdoch), the deal underscores growing media consolidation under oligarchs. It follows a broader pattern—Musk (X), Zuckerberg (Facebook/Instagram), Bezos (Washington Post)—where wealthy owners shape news agendas, often curbing nuance and dissent. With control over TikTok’s algorithm poised to influence one in five Americans (and nearly half of under-30s), critics warn of heightened self-censorship and political sway. While the transaction still needs Chinese approval, it signals an intensified takeover of digital information by the ultra-rich.

articles.title: Starmerism has almost destroyed the Labour party, but I still have hope for renewal | Clive Lewis
articles.trailText: As our party conference gets under way this weekend in Liverpool, we must start to work out how we can inspire the country, says Labour MP Clive Lewis
articles.summary: As Labour’s conference begins in Liverpool, Clive Lewis warns Starmerism has flattened the party’s radical energy into centralised control: soft-left promises have yielded top-down candidate selection, marginalised grassroots and left voices, a rejection of coalition politics and public ownership, and timid climate action beholden to corporate influence. This managerial, neoliberal drift risks ceding ground to authoritarian populism. Yet Lewis finds hope in community organisers, co-ops, unions and local participatory budgets. Renewal, he argues, must emerge from below, empowering citizens not just collecting votes.

articles.title: Optus’s triple zero debacle is further proof of the failure of the neoliberal experiment | John Quiggin
articles.trailText: Privately owned monopolies always look to increase profits at the expense of consumers. Australia must hasten its return to public ownership of vital infrastructure
articles.summary: John Quiggin argues Optus’s triple zero outage exposes neoliberal privatisation failures: fragmented emergency networks, delayed outage reporting, offshore call centres and cost-cutting that undermine public safety. He shows that telecom price drops predated deregulation, while competition spawned redundant urban fibre, rural coverage gaps and Telstra’s enduring dominance. Successive policy shifts—from forced fibre duopolies to the NBN wholesale model—reflect telecoms as a natural monopoly. Quiggin calls for abandoning ineffective regulation and accelerating the return of critical infrastructure to public ownership.

articles.title: Starmer should have conference in his hands – instead, power is slipping through his fingers | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: Last year’s triumph has turned into a groundhog day loop of missed chances and bad calls. The PM needs to change tack – but is he capable of it? asks Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: One year after Labour’s landslide, Keir Starmer faces slipping poll ratings, three scandalous exits and MPs plotting his ousting. Frances Ryan criticises his managerial “delivery, delivery” style for avoidable missteps—from indecision on Gaza and half-hearted benefit reforms to muddled asylum and immigration policies—and failure to tackle child poverty or improve public services. As Reform UK surges, his pledge against far-right divisions feels late and lacks a clear vision. Without a compelling narrative on social justice, economic renewal and humane migration, Starmer risks squandering his mandate and opening the door to a nationalist backlash.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Nato airspace incursions: Russia is testing European and US will. It won’t stop here | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The escalation in recent days is raising alarm. It forms part of Moscow’s broader pattern of probing and provocation
articles.summary: In just over two weeks, Russian drones and fighter jets breached Polish, Romanian, Estonian, German, Danish, Copenhagen and Oslo airspace, grounding flights and forcing expensive scrambles. Though Moscow denies responsibility, the incidents fit its pattern of probing NATO’s military readiness and will to support Ukraine. Divergent member views—from downing intruders to fearing escalation—hamper a unified response. Trump’s Alaska remarks advocating downing intruders deepen doubts over US commitment and expose NATO rifts. Beyond airspace, suspected Russian undersea cable sabotage, dam-hacking and GRU operations signal a multi-domain campaign testing European and US resolve and exposing critical infrastructure vulnerabilities.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Ireland’s presidential election: a contest with consequences | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Since 1990, the heads of state of Britain’s closest neighbour have played important soft power roles. This needs to continue
articles.summary: Ireland will elect on 24 October a successor to President Michael D Higgins, whose two seven-year terms have bolstered the ceremonial office’s soft-power role and improved British–Irish ties after his 2014 state visit. Celebrities like Flatley and McGregor failed to secure nominations, leaving a contest between Fianna Fáil-backed Jim Gavin, Fine Gael’s Heather Humphreys (slightly ahead in early polls) and independent Catherine Connolly, backed by Sinn Féin, Labour and the Social Democrats. Voters’ choice will shape Ireland’s presidency into the volatile 2030s amid post-Brexit tensions, potential human rights convention shifts and debates over a unification referendum.

articles.title: Labour must grab the microphone from Reform UK and stand up for true British values | Lucy Powell
articles.trailText: If elected deputy Labour leader, I would take the fight to Nigel Farage and show him for what he really is, says Labour MP Lucy Powell
articles.summary: Labour MP Lucy Powell, campaigning for deputy leadership, urges the party to wrest the political megaphone from Reform UK’s Nigel Farage by exposing his divisive, simplistic immigration rhetoric—most outrageously his plan to deport legally settled residents—and reclaiming a values-based narrative. She calls on Labour to champion deep-rooted economic equality, highlight achievements on workplace rights, minimum wage, public ownership and NHS expansion, engage progressive and swing voters, address border control and asylum housing honestly, and harness intellectual confidence to counter the hard right’s agenda.

articles.title: ‘Reply guys’ exist in the inboxes of multiple women simultaneously. When a target finally responds, they retreat. Why? | Lucinda Price
articles.trailText: A ‘reply guy’s modus operandi is simple: maintain multiple low-effort conversations as possible. But his motives? Largely unclear
articles.summary: A ‘reply guy’—typically male—simultaneously maintains lightweight conversations with numerous women, reacting to stories with jokes or compliments without genuine follow-through. When a woman finally engages, the reply guy disappears, only to resume messaging weeks later when she posts again. Many are in relationships and seek validation rather than intimacy. This behavior differs from breadcrumbing or orbiting, frustrating targets who crave clear intentions. Price suggests aggregating reply guys into a shared group chat to channel their compulsive outreach and possibly address male loneliness.

articles.title: Trump wants to rebrand his tax bill as the ‘Working Families Tax Cut’. Don’t be fooled | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: The budget measure will hurt poor people and boost rich people. It should really be called the Billionaires’ Tax Cut Act
articles.summary: President Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act—rebranded as the “Working Families Tax Cut”—slashes $1.4tn from Medicaid, food assistance and student aid, while delivering 45% of next year’s tax cuts to the top 5% of households. CBO analysis shows the bottom 10% lose $1,214 annually and most working families net losers, despite modest $750–$1,500 standard deduction raises. The wealthiest gain $103,500 on average and benefit from a $30m estate tax exemption. Critics call it the Billionaires’ Tax Cut Act and warn tariffs further undermine low‐income Americans. Polls show 46% disapprove.

articles.title: Norway's king and queen faced a serious accusation on Netflix – here's why Norwegians rushed to defend them | Shazia Majid
articles.trailText: Their son-in-law said they were ‘ignorant of racism’, but immigrant families like mine know how baseless that charge is, says Norwegian journalist Shazia Majid
articles.summary: When Netflix’s Rebel Royals doc premiered, Durek Verrett accused King Harald and Queen Sonja of ignorance toward racism. In response, immigrants and minority groups across Norway spontaneously defended the monarchs, citing decades of speeches and initiatives—Harald’s inclusive New Year’s messages naming immigrants from Asia, Africa and Europe, Sonja’s advocacy for women and minorities—and consistent efforts to welcome diverse communities. Critics note Norway’s remaining racial tensions and Verrett’s pseudoscientific controversies, but argue that mislabeling allies as racist undermines genuine anti-discrimination work and distorts the royal couple’s unifying role.

articles.title: Transgender Americans are seeing a wave of hate unleashed by Charlie Kirk’s killing | Erin Reed
articles.trailText: In the aftermath of Kirk’s death, the far-right and Trump administration have turned up attacks on transgender people
articles.summary: After Charlie Kirk’s shooting, Republicans and the Trump administration amplified anti-trans hate, falsely blamed trans people—including debunked claims that bullets bore transgender symbols—and launched new rhetoric and policy attacks. Officials like Nancy Mace and Ronny Jackson called for institutionalizing trans Americans as a “virus,” while Congress fast-tracked appropriations riders banning gender-affirming care, Pride flags on military bases and trans bathroom access. Trump is leveraging anti-trans provisions to force a government shutdown, filed an emergency Supreme Court bid to rescind passport gender corrections and signals plans to brand trans rights groups as domestic terrorists, prompting fear and plans to flee among trans communities.

articles.title: We are sailing to Gaza. Here’s why | David Adler
articles.trailText: Governments have failed the people of Gaza. Now, ordinary people are taking humanitarian matters into their own hands – and putting their lives on the line
articles.summary: David Adler, co-general coordinator of Progressive International, sails aboard Family, the lead motor-cruiser of the unprecedented 40-boat Global Sumud Flotilla departing Barcelona to Gaza with hundreds of volunteers—doctors, lawyers, journalists, parliamentarians and activists from 40+ nations. Spurred by an independent UN commission’s genocide finding and UN Resolution ES-10/24, they fill the void left by governments that continue arming Israel. Facing Israeli claims of terror links, repeated drone attacks in Tunisian waters and threats of force, flotilla participants conduct non-violent drills and call on states to join their maritime humanitarian corridor rather than siege Gaza from land.

articles.title: The next big financial crisis may be brewing. Warning signs are already there | Larry Elliott
articles.trailText: The longer the period between crises, the greater the complacency. That complacency is pushing share prices ever-higher, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: US share prices are at record highs despite stalling job creation, rising unemployment and tariff-driven import costs. Trump’s public feud with Fed chair Jerome Powell, whom he wants ousted, underpins market confidence that rate cuts will prop up equities. Historical complacency after 17 years without a severe crash, buoyed by AI-driven growth bets, masks risks. With inflation near 3% and growth mediocre, 30% of US wealth tied to stocks—concentrated among top earners—sustains spending. The Fed faces a stark choice: tighten to curb inflation and risk recession, or cut to support markets and fuel a larger bubble.

articles.title: Corbyn and Sultana have a half-formed party with huge potential, and our politics needs it | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: Vast numbers want a party that counters the country’s rightward lurch. Despite the chaos, they are willing Your Party to get off the ground, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana’s nascent “Your Party” has stumbled through public feuds, weak structures and high-profile resignations, but taps into widespread disillusionment with Britain’s conservative consensus. Ten times as many members signed up this summer than joined the Greens (now 80,000 strong), signalling huge potential ahead of its 29–30 November founding conference. Amid low turnout and uniform right-leaning policy from the Tories, Labour and Reform UK, Your Party offers an anti-austerity, pro-equality platform tackling inequality, privatisation and racist immigration myths. Its survival will depend on turning initial chaos into cohesive organisation to reshape UK left-wing politics.

articles.title: Special relationship? There can be no such thing with a snake like Trump | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer has spent the best part of a year cosying up to the US president. It will be no surprise when he gets bitten, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty invokes Donald Trump’s favourite poem, “The Snake”, to illustrate how Keir Starmer’s courting of Trump and pursuit of US tech investment risks UK sovereignty. He argues the touted £31bn “record-breaking” deal channels foreign capital into hyperscale datacentres owned by Silicon Valley giants, creating minimal local jobs, straining energy and water infrastructure and ceding control of AI “plumbing”. After photo-ops at Windsor Castle and Chequers, Trump’s insult (“Old World shitholes”) reveals the relationship’s venom. Chakrabortty warns Britain is becoming a vassal state, vulnerable to US geopolitical “kill switches”.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the climate crisis: green energy is booming – but fossil fuels need to shrink too | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The planet is nearing dangerous limits. Yet progress on clean energy shows what’s possible. With political will, cooperation can still avert the worst of the climate crisis
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns seven of nine planetary boundaries are breached, urging an end to the fossil-fuel era and a step-change in clean energy. It cites a record $386bn in renewables investment in H1 2025, China’s 250GW solar build, $2.2tn global clean-energy spend versus fossil, and criticizes EU NDC delays and the US Paris withdrawal ahead of this month’s climate pledges, calling for bolder targets and political leadership to avert extreme heating.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s support for Ukraine: a welcome but not reliable vote of confidence | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Having exhausted a failed policy of appeasement, the US president may at last be ready to put pressure on Moscow
articles.summary: For all his history of favouring appeasement, Trump now claims Kyiv can achieve total victory, offers to extend US arms transfers through Nato and to shoot down Russian jets 'if they're attacking'. Having urged Zelenskyy to surrender and praised Putin in March, the president’s stance has shifted only with European prodding, veering between admiration, patience and frustration towards Moscow. His grandstanding peacemaker gambit and self-aggrandising impulses make any endorsement of tougher sanctions or military aid welcome but far from dependable. Western allies should exploit this strategic opening, yet remain wary of abrupt reversals.

articles.title: With Kimmel’s suspension, the FCC chair has made himself Trump’s comedian-in-chief | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: Brendan Carr, head of the Federal Communications Commission, is fulfilling the ‘authoritarian’s dream’ he once decried
articles.summary: FCC chair Brendan Carr, who once decried censorship as the 'authoritarian’s dream,' pressured Disney, Nexstar and Sinclair to indefinitely suspend ABC’s Jimmy Kimmel over a remark on the far right’s handling of Charlie Kirk’s assassin. Speaking on Benny Johnson’s hard-right podcast, Carr threatened regulation, executing Project 2025’s media purge to shield Trump from critique. Kimmel’s brief ouster galvanized free-speech advocates and highlighted the FCC’s politicized censorship before his reinstatement. His duplicity undermines the FCC’s role as a guardian of free expression and exposes a broader campaign to silence dissenting comedy and political critique.

articles.title: Trump’s UN rant revealed his true priorities – and Britain should watch out | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: Less than a week after his state visit, the president launched a surprise attack on the UK – and sent a clear signal about US power, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Just days after a friendly UK state visit, Trump used his 57-minute UN speech to pivot from praise to provocation, boasting about ending “un-endable” wars, offering a $500m HQ overhaul and trash-talking the UN and globalism. He reversed on Ukraine—backing NATO arms, shooting down Russian planes—and dismissed climate accords, migration and international law. Britain bore the brunt of his ire over green energy, North Sea oil, migration and Palestine. Kettle argues this rant underlines Trump’s sovereign-first agenda and signals a growing transatlantic strain.

articles.title: Elizabeth Gilbert’s memoir has raised eyebrows – but she always comes out on top | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: A new tale from the longtime purveyor of self-love is both horrific and poorly done, and nobody’s sure how to respond, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Elizabeth Gilbert’s latest memoir, All the Way to the River, recounts her final years with late partner Rayya Elias, tracing Elias’s cancer diagnosis, spiraling addiction and paranoia, and Gilbert’s own enabling role. Despite Gilbert’s track record—from Eat Pray Love to Big Magic—critics have branded the book a ‘solipsistic mess,’ ‘excruciating’ yet ‘moving,’ lamenting thin material, awkward spirit-channelling and a dubious wardrobe homage. Still, buoyed by Gilbert’s enormous goodwill, the memoir debuted at No. 2 on the New York Times bestseller list.

articles.title: Why does it take so long to repair a broken lift? | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: Too many people use too few lifts and – as I learned at a recent visit to the hospital – getting to the 26th floor can bring out the worst in people, writes Guardian columnist Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles recounts a fraught hospital visit to a 26th-floor clinic where only one working lift forced a 20-minute queue, scuffles and silent hostilities as staff regulars and novices jockeyed for position. A lift engineer explains delays: drive-unit failures take months to fix because many buildings are “underlifted,” wearing out equipment. Chiles observes how cramped elevator etiquette reveals human behaviour—hostility, courtesy and silent dramas—and flags a broader quality-of-life issue in London’s high-rises, where lift scarcity hampers mobility and daily life.

articles.title: Reminiscing with old classmates taught me that some memories only scratch the surface of the truth | Vivienne Pearson
articles.trailText: I expected to have fun sharing recollections, but I was disconcerted to discover my memories didn’t stand up to others’ retellings
articles.summary: Vivienne Pearson’s account of a 1980s school reunion explores how personal memories often diverge from shared reality. Reconnecting with classmates, she recalls tales of No-Doz tablets, tin-mug campfire drinks and the 1983 Melbourne dust storm, only to find conflicting or forgotten details. Through laughter, selfies and heartfelt moments, Pearson confronts the fickleness and subjectivity of memory, pondering its philosophical limits and legal unreliability. A standout moment comes from her former English teacher, Mr Lyons, whose accurate recollection of her family underscores the remarkable complexity of human memory.

articles.title: I was elected mayor of Istanbul, but I write this from jail: Turkish democracy is under grave threat | Ekrem Imamoğlu
articles.trailText: If our nation slides deeper into autocracy, the consequences will reverberate far beyond Turkey’s borders, says Istanbul’s suspended mayor Ekrem Imamoğlu
articles.summary: Istanbul mayor Ekrem İmamoğlu, jailed since March on politically motivated corruption and terrorism charges after his academic credentials were annulled, warns Turkey faces a slide into autocracy under Erdoğan’s rule. More than a dozen opposition mayors and hundreds of activists, journalists and academics are imprisoned, elected officials replaced with state trustees, and the CHP’s leadership under legal assault. İmamoğlu outlines a CHP roadmap for democratic transition—restoring judicial independence, combating corruption, rebuilding institutions—and urges international solidarity to resist Erdoğan’s authoritarian drift, whose ripple effects could threaten democracy globally.

articles.title: Trump delivered an embarassing performance at the UN general assembly | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: This was Trump unfiltered and unleashed – as he has been since the start of his second term, with no restraint and no need for even the mildest niceties
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly, Trump delivered a rambling, unfiltered 60-minute diatribe full of personal grievances—griping about a bad teleprompter and stalled escalator, rehashing a failed UN HQ bid, and hectoring allies. He launched tirades on immigration—bragging about U.S. border crackdowns, urging Europe to close borders and stop a “globalist migration agenda”—insulted London mayor Sadiq Khan, ridiculed climate science as “the greatest con,” denounced renewables, praised coal, and warned green energy and migration would destroy Western Europe.

articles.title: AI investors are in for a rude awakening | Roger McNamee
articles.trailText: There is a huge gap between investment and revenue from LLMs. Investors wrongly assume everyone will be a winner
articles.summary: Roger McNamee warns that over US$717bn has poured into LLMs since 2022 and could double by 2026, eclipsing all prior tech investment. At least five or six major players (Google, Amazon, Meta, xAI, Microsoft/OpenAI) plus suppliers (Nvidia, Apple, Anthropic) are each seeking costly global monopolies. Yet public LLM sales were just ~$1bn in 2023, ~$4bn in 2024, with infrastructure swallowing most $235–244bn 2025 revenues. Forecasts project $1tn AI revenue by 2031 but hinge on huge further capex. McNamee argues that only two winners can profit, leaving multiple billion-dollar write-offs ahead and a harsh reckoning for investors.

articles.title: The American system is badly broken | Bernie Sanders
articles.trailText: What we are witnessing right now is the rise of two Americas. One for the billionaire class. And one for everybody else
articles.summary: Senator Bernie Sanders argues that the US is split into two Americas: one where billionaires like Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and Larry Ellison control over $1.3 trillion and enjoy tax breaks, private jets, mansions and $1 trillion pay packages; and a second where most Americans face stagnant real wages lower than 52 years ago, unaffordable healthcare, a housing crisis with 800,000 homeless, surging rents and tuition, inadequate schools and insecure retirements. He warns oligarchy threatens democracy and calls for collective action to build an economy that works for all. Quoting Justice Brandeis, he insists democracy and wealth concentration cannot coexist.

articles.title: Pregnant women deserve so much better than Trump’s theatre of scaremongering and shame | Kate Womersley
articles.trailText: There is no credible evidence linking autism with maternal paracetamol use. But the US president’s ‘tough it out’ message could harm mothers and babies, says doctor Kate Womersley
articles.summary: In a staged White House appearance with RFK Jr and Dr. Oz, President Trump urged pregnant women to ‘tough it out’ and avoid paracetamol over an unproven autism link. Dr. Kate Womersley, citing a 2024 Swedish study of 2.5 million births that found no maternal acetaminophen association with neurodiversity, warns this fear-mongering pits women’s needs against fetal health and risks driving them to more hazardous treatments. She calls for robust, inclusive pregnancy research—like her Message Maternity initiative—to replace speculation with evidence and protect mothers and babies.

articles.title: Resisting Faragism offers the Lib Dems a rare clarity of purpose | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: Ed Davey’s rallying cry in defence of moderate, liberal Britain might give some coherence to a party with a reputation for opportunism, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: At their Bournemouth conference, leader Ed Davey framed the Liberal Democrats as defenders of moderate liberal democracy, rallying one-nation Conservatives dismayed by Kemi Badenoch’s rightward shift and ex-Labour voters disappointed by Starmer’s compromises. By emphasising opposition to Farage’s divisive populism—linking his style to Trumpian xenophobia—and advocating re-integration via a customs union, Davey aims to build a local anti-Farage coalition in target seats. This pitch taps Brexit backlash, clarifies the party’s purpose beyond historical opportunism, and underscores a binary choice: tolerant, civic patriots versus Faragist extremists.

articles.title: If Europe keeps placating its own far right, how can it possibly stand up to Trump? | Thu Nguyen and Jannik Jansen
articles.trailText: European leaders’ weakness is undermining the democratic principles on which the EU was built, say Thu Nguyen and Jannik Jansen from the Jacques Delors Centre
articles.summary: Nguyen and Jansen argue that EU leaders’ concessions to Trump on tariffs and their appeasement of domestic far-right parties—from tough migration deals and tolerated pushbacks to diluted climate ambition—undermine the democratic principles, rule of law and multilateralism at the heart of the “European way.” These compromises, framed as pragmatism under electoral pressure, risk legitimising extremist views, hollowing out EU political agency and credibility. The authors call for a recommitment to pluralism, open societies and climate action to counter authoritarianism. They warn this pattern not only erodes solidarity on Ukraine but also weakens Europe’s credibility on human rights, as seen in its tepid Gaza response.

articles.title: Why do the children of elderly patients stay away? Loneliness makes them get sicker and stay sicker for longer | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: One of the greatest acts of love is simply bearing witness to the vicissitudes of ageing
articles.summary: In this personal essay, oncologist Ranjana Srivastava examines how loneliness in hospitalised patients over 75—often living alone and without family visits—worsens heart failure, frailty, cognitive decline and prolongs recovery. While one case of three sons boosting their nonagenarian father’s morale led to rapid improvement, many elderly suffer isolation due to children’s work, distance or emotional barriers. Srivastava contrasts Western patterns with Vietnamese and Greek filial care, arguing that prioritising acts of presence is a vital antidote to a societal malady no medicine can cure.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Sir Ed Davey’s speech: a party that promises contrast and protest | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Liberal Democrat leader drew a moral line on Gaza, challenged rightwing populism and targeted Labour. It’s not reinvention but an ethical intent
articles.summary: Sir Ed Davey’s conference speech reframed the Liberal Democrats around ethical clarity over reinvention: he was the first UK leader to label Gaza a ‘genocide’, drawing a stark moral line ahead of Starmer’s ambivalence. He proposed centre-left policies—a cancer treatment guarantee, greater support for carers, green energy investment—and called for Elon Musk’s arrest for facilitating far-right violence. Davey outlined re-engagement with the EU via customs union and single market access, positioning the Lib Dems as a force against populism, Labour complacency and irrelevance, and pledging clear moral contrast in a fracturing political landscape.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Welsh politics: a new era threatens to leave Labour out in the cold | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: After enjoying unparalleled political hegemony in Wales for over a hundred years, the party of Aneurin Bevan and Neil Kinnock has lost its way
articles.summary: Wales’s Labour party, dominant since 1922 and winners of every Senedd election since 1999, faces a potential shock at next May’s poll, with YouGov placing Plaid Cymru on 30%, Reform UK on 29% and Labour trailing on 14%. A Caerphilly by-election will test this meltdown. Scandals around Vaughan Gething, rising NHS waiting lists and alignment with unpopular Westminster policies—such as the two-child benefit cap—have driven left-leaning voters to Plaid, while Reform UK eclipses the Conservatives on the right. A shift to 96 proportional Senedd seats could cement a new political era. Eluned Morgan urges a distinct ‘red Welsh way’ and greater UK investment; without radical Starmer-led reform, Labour’s century-long hegemony is at risk.

articles.title: Someone has to drag the US out of the hellscape of Trumpism. Who better than AOC? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Yes, the Democratic congresswoman is flawed – but she’s a fighter. Let’s not write her off as too young or too female, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Mahdawi criticizes the US ‘gerontocracy’ of aging elites and notes eight Democratic lawmakers have died in office since 2022. She argues Americans now favor fresh progressive voices—Zohran Mamdani, Bernie Sanders and especially Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez—over establishment figures like Pelosi, Schumer and Jeffries. Rumors of AOC running for Senate or president in 2028 suggest a seismic generational shift if she unseats Schumer or wins a nomination. Despite losing DSA backing over her Palestine stance, Mahdawi insists AOC’s fighting spirit is crucial to drag US politics out of Trumpism.

articles.title: The consensus is clear: it’s genocide. Now will international law die in Gaza too? | Raji Sourani
articles.trailText: The clue is in the name: the convention on the prevention and punishment of the crime of genocide. When will we act?, asks Raji Sourani, the coordinator of the Palestinian legal team at the international criminal court
articles.summary: Raji Sourani, director of the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights and ICC legal coordinator, warns that a UN commission’s finding—backed by survivor testimony—that Israel commits genocide in Gaza underscores both mass killing and systematic targeting of civilians amid siege and bombardment. He notes belated state recognition of Palestine by the UK and others hasn’t halted starvation, displacement or attacks on human rights defenders and journalists documenting crimes. Sourani argues international law risks collapse without enforcement: he urges arms embargoes, ending US/UK support, and concrete action to uphold the Genocide Convention’s preventive and punitive mandate.

articles.title: Trump’s absurd Tylenol claims heighten the suffering of pregnant women in the US | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: There is no evidence to support the president’s assertions about autism. But they exploit fears that already come with pregnancy
articles.summary: Moira Donegan deconstructs a shambolic White House event where President Trump, joined by RFK Jr. and Mehmet Oz, peddled unfounded claims that acetaminophen use in pregnancy causes autism—a distortion of flawed correlational studies contradicted by experts and ignoring the proven fetal risks of untreated fevers. She shows how this cynical fearmongering compounds real harms from abortion bans, Medicaid cuts, vaccine misinformation and systemic neglect of pregnant women’s health, taps into a shameful culture of shaming pregnant women, magnifying fears amid Supreme Court reproductive rollbacks and provider shortages.

articles.title: Spare a thought for right-royal victim Duchess Fergie – it’s been another truly hellacious week | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: As more gushing emails emerge, Sarah Ferguson is once again rethinking her ‘supreme’ friendship with the super-rich sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Sarah Ferguson’s repeated claim to be an innocent ‘victim’ of Jeffrey Epstein’s lies. Despite a 2011 public apology and vow to shun him after his 2008 conviction for underage abuse, newly released emails reveal Fergie fawningly thanking Epstein for gifts and denying she called him a ‘paedophile.’ Charities have severed ties amid her history of debt-fuelled spending and reliance on wealthy benefactors. Hyde argues true survivors wouldn’t glamorize or ignore clear evidence of abuse, exposing Fergie’s self-styled victimhood as cynical and undeserved.

articles.title: Charlie Kirk was a divisive far-right podcaster. Why is he being rebranded as a national hero? | Saida Grundy
articles.trailText: Celebrating a bigoted rage-baiter sends a clear message to people of color, LGBTQ+ folks and women
articles.summary: After Charlie Kirk’s September 10 killing, the White House flew flags at half-staff, Congress held moments of silence and passed a eulogizing resolution, and NFL teams staged in-game memorials, recasting the 31-year-old far-right podcaster as a national martyr. Kirk’s platform thrived on racist, xenophobic and misogynistic rage-baiting, dehumanizing opponents and mobilizing youth. Saida Grundy argues these state-sponsored tributes echo neo-Confederate memorials: they elevate extremist ideology, silence dissent, and send a renewed message to people of color, women and LGBTQ+ communities about whose values the government upholds. By canonizing Kirk, modern memorialization distorts historical memory and consolidates white nationalist narratives.

articles.title: Jimmy Kimmel is coming back. It’s proof that you still have power | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: Disney saw hurricane-level blowback over the talkshow host’s suspension, thanks in large part to consumers
articles.summary: Less than a week after FCC chair Brendan Carr threatened ABC over Jimmy Kimmel’s political comments, Disney suspended Jimmy Kimmel Live!, citing ‘ill-timed’ remarks and pausing production ‘to avoid inflaming’ a tense national moment. After ‘thoughtful conversations’ with Kimmel, Disney reversed course. Furious entertainment unions, late-night hosts, actors and even Ted Cruz decried corporate cowardice and free speech threats. Consumer cancellations of Disney+ and Hulu subscriptions, along with a $4bn stock drop, forced Disney to reinstate the show. Robert Reich argues this episode proves the power of public outrage and consumer dollars to safeguard speech when politics fails.

articles.title: My blood type made me a donor superhero – until my weakness for crisps let me down | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: ‘It’s such a shame,’ said the nurse as she turned me away from the donation centre, and I realised my assumptions about being O-negative were all wrong
articles.summary: In her Guardian column, Zoe Williams recounts being turned away from blood donation for a marginally low iron level despite her prized O-negative status. After a strict three-strikes rule imposes a two-year ban, she realizes that many donors share her blood type. A nurse admonishes her to eat more vegetables and cut out crisps to raise iron. Williams, who embraces short sleep and indifference to boasting, reflects on how snack habits and rigid donor policies upended her ‘superhero’ identity as a universal donor.

articles.title: I've seen Labour's cursed deputy leader role up close. It should finally be abolished | Richard Heller
articles.trailText: I worked for Denis Healey when he held the post, so know just how useless it is – and how much better both the country and Labour would be without it, says author Richard Heller
articles.summary: Amid Keir Starmer’s reshuffle and the contest between Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell, Richard Heller argues Labour’s deputy leader role is redundant, powerless and beset by thankless tasks—from procedural wrangling and ceremonial duties to appeasing factions—while stoking internal rivalry. Drawing on his experience with Denis Healey and examples like Attlee, Beckett’s interim leadership and the Healey–Benn clash, he calls on Labour to abolish the post via a “none-of-the-above” option to preserve unity and efficiency.

articles.title: The populist right wants to remake the UK in the image of Dubai. We should all be careful what they wish for | Jonathan Liew
articles.trailText: Politicians and influencers eulogise the emirate as a place of cleanliness, convenience and low crime. The truth is far darker, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew critiques the populist right’s admiration of Dubai’s slick, low-crime, 24/7 convenience model, warning that its glossy facade hides authoritarianism, labor exploitation and severe inequality. Influencers and figures like Piers Morgan and Reform UK laud Emirati-style visa controls, nationalistic schooling and harsh deportations, while ignoring migrant worker camps, lack of rights, gender and sexual repression and systematic subservience. Liew argues this vision—echoed in calls for a “white Dubai”—threatens democratic norms and workers’ protections, serving a hard-right utopia built on ruthless state control, racial hierarchy and an invisible underclass.

articles.title: The hard right is claiming the cross – and true Christians should not allow it | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: British church leaders have finally spoken out about the dangerous rise of Christian nationalism. But their message was far too timid, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee warns Britain faces a home-grown Christian nationalism: far-right figures like Tommy Robinson and Reform UK cloak racist, anti-immigrant agitation in Christian symbolism. She criticises church leaders’ meek open letter against ‘misuse of the cross’ and Labour’s reluctance to confront xenophobic demagogues. Toynbee exposes wealthy evangelist funders behind hardline conservative clergy and urges political leaders – especially the Church of England and government – to renounce Christian nationalism and defend pluralist values before tribal nativism corrodes democracy.

articles.title: Europe has lost one superpower ally – can it afford to be in the crosshairs of two? | Nathalie Tocci
articles.trailText: For years, the EU followed the US’s lead when it came to China. That is no longer an option and Beijing has other priorities, says Guardian journalist Nathalie Tocci
articles.summary: Europe, once guided by US China policy, now finds its transatlantic anchor gone and faces a fraught China strategy. Brussels moved from trade-focused engagement to “de-risking” under US pressure, but today’s American unpredictability leaves the EU weighing protectionism, Chinese green-tech cooperation or an Asia-wide trade alliance. Two core dilemmas intensify the challenge: defending liberal democracy against China-inspired illiberal forces, and confronting Beijing’s tacit support for Russia in Ukraine, trapping Europe between two superpowers.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s NHS reforms: where is the plan to deliver them?
articles.trailText: Editorial: Bold announcements about restructuring appear to have taken priority over implementation
articles.summary: The Guardian view criticises Labour’s NHS reforms for prioritising bold restructuring over delivery. Despite a record £22.6bn funding boost, inflation, rising NI contributions and resident doctors’ 22.3% pay award have limited frontline improvements. Hospital waiting lists, after six months of decline, have ticked back up, and staffing shortages and low patient satisfaction persist. Plans to halve running costs at 42 integrated care boards are threatened by unaffordable redundancies, while merging NHS England with the DHSC imperils 15,000 posts. With a projected £6.6bn overspend and local devolution proposals looming, the editorial warns that incessant reorganisations risk derailing the 10-year plan’s goals.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Donald Trump’s hate for opponents: practising politics the wrong way | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The president’s admission is more than bravado. By blurring truth and criminalising dissent, he is dismantling the US’s free-speech order from within
articles.summary: At a memorial for Charlie Kirk, Trump declared 'I hate my opponents…' revealing his strategy to criminalize disliked speech rather than hate speech per se. By equating dissent with disloyalty, framing satire as terrorism and pressuring employers and platforms, he chills free expression and subverts the First Amendment’s self-governance. His two-pronged assault – partisan media harassment networks and threats to social media licensing – warps debate and fuels viral misinformation. Unlike other democracies that balance free speech with harm prevention, Trump's model rewards allies, degrades honest discourse and erodes democratic norms. Restoring robust public-square rules and platform accountability is essential.

articles.title: From dark academia to medievalcore: fashion is embracing our need for escapism | Lauren Cochcrane
articles.trailText: Much is written about how young people no longer form real-world communities. Well, fashion trends are a stark rejoinder to that, says senior Guardian fashion writer Lauren Cochrane
articles.summary: In her Guardian column, Lauren Cochrane traces Gen Z’s evolving ‘core’ microtrends—from normcore’s ordinariness to dark academia’s bookish gatherings and medievalcore’s corsets, chainmail and long skirts. Medievalcore’s red-carpet nods (Millie Bobby Brown), 20,000+ TikTok posts and 110% spike in Pinterest searches reflect young people’s craving for escapism and offline community.
