This throwback aesthetic borrows from 600-year-old styles and historical heroines like Joan of Arc, offering immersive identity play akin to gaming avatars. While fast fashion fuels rapid trend cycles, enduring ‘cores’—from cottagecore’s rural romance to dark academia—reveal a deeper desire for belonging, creative play and historical fantasy.

articles.title: Your Party is a mess. Here’s what they could learn from Farage and Polanski | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The public clearly has an appetite for the ideals being offered by the new Sultana-Corbyn alliance. But those involved in the project have to act in harmony - and stay on topic, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Corbyn and Sultana’s new ‘Your Party’ movement, launched without cohesive messaging or even a clear name, has drawn 600,000 sign-ups in under a week but been widely mocked for internal miscommunication – notably Zarah Sultana announcing co-leadership without Jeremy Corbyn’s prior knowledge. An open letter by Yanis Varoufakis and Ken Loach urged unity and discipline. Critics contrast its scattergun agenda with the focused, relentless campaigning of Nigel Farage and Zack Polanski. The left must adopt single-issue coherence to engage voters effectively.

articles.title: Corbyn and Sultana: the needs of the left are greater than any of your differences | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Millions of UK voters are desperate for radical change. For their sake, we must hope Your Party’s hotheads give way to calm strategists, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Independent MPs Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana drew 750,000 sign-ups for their placeholder “Your Party”, but a co-leadership dispute nearly derailed launch until legal threats were dropped. Owen Jones urges calm strategy to mobilise youth, grassroots Muslims and a Greens alliance against Keir Starmer’s rightward pivot—crackdowns on migrants, refusal to tax elites and service cuts. With mass backing for public ownership and wealth taxes, only a united left confronting Islamophobia, defending minority rights and addressing economic insecurity can challenge entrenched elites, rising authoritarianism and the far right reshaping Britain.

articles.title: I took my daughter on a holiday to Hong Kong to visit family. I didn’t realise how hard it would be to leave | Lucille Wong
articles.trailText: I recognised the longing to be in two places at once. When you have two worlds, you always have to say goodbye to one
articles.summary: Melbourne-based writer Lucille Wong recounts a two-week school holiday trip to Hong Kong with her nearly seven-year-old daughter to spend time with her 90s grandmother after her grandfather’s death. Despite initial worries over accommodation in a spare bedroom, lack of playdates and typhoon season, they establish a daily routine of breakfasts with “tai pau,” swimming, ferry rides, street wandering and last-minute Hong Kong-style playdates. The daughter bonds with cousins and a building friend, adopts local quirks, buys pet turtles and learns Cantonese. On departure they face dual-world longing—goodbyes to new friends and family—while cherishing memories and bilingual identity.

articles.title: Judith Butler is being targeted by the US government. We must stand up | Joel Swanson
articles.trailText: What is happening to Judith Butler – a Jewish intellectual – in the name of fighting ‘antisemitism’ is outrageous
articles.summary: UC Berkeley handed a list of 160 names of faculty, staff and students to the Trump administration investigating antisemitism incidents; among them is Judith Butler, the prominent Jewish queer theorist. Butler’s public targeting in the name of “fighting antisemitism” echoes McCarthy-era antisemitism, when Jews deemed politically deviant were blacklisted and surveilled under the McCarran-Walter Act. Swanson highlights how Jewish organizations like the AJC and ADL collaborated then and now to suppress leftist Jewish dissent for respectability. He urges the Jewish community to defend all Jews—not just those with mainstream politics—and uphold a diverse Jewish intellectual tradition.

articles.title: America’s leadership class is failing us. It’s up to you and me to defend democracy | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The disappearance of America’s leadership class at a time like this means that the rest of us have to be leaders
articles.summary: Robert Reich argues that as the Trump administration strips constitutional rights, the nation’s traditional leadership—from university presidents and religious figures to CEOs, lawyers, media executives and politicians—has fallen silent or caved in to self-interest and fear. He cites examples like Berkeley quietly handing over pro-Palestinian protester names, business leaders praising the president, and party officials unwilling to oppose violations of free speech and due process. Reich insists genuine leadership doesn’t require formal titles but moral courage, urging citizens to step up and defend democracy themselves.

articles.title: I sought to protect an immigrant legal client. Instead, I’m facing Trump’s new sanctions
articles.trailText: I appear to be the first attorney targeted in a scheme that calls on federal agencies to accuse lawyers of unethical conduct
articles.summary: On Memorial Day 2025, a solo immigration attorney secured a Texas court order to block his client’s removal to Laos, only to see him flown out overnight and deplaned in Guam. He filed a new habeas petition there to prevent statelessness, then learned the DOJ—following a Trump administration directive—moved to sanction him personally for ethical misconduct. This unprecedented tactic aims to chill pro bono representation of indigent immigrants, jeopardizing lawyers’ careers and undermining due process, judicial independence and broader individual and immigrant rights.

articles.title: Stop sneering at mothers. Most of us have done things you wouldn’t believe | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Sure, I personally am terminally cautious and aesthetically unadventurous – but I’m the exception
articles.summary: Emma Beddington criticizes the clichéd marketing trope 'not your mother’s…' — originally spun off the 1988 'not your father’s Oldsmobile' ad — for its sexist, ageist dismissal of women’s adventurous pasts. While Beddington identifies as cautious, she recalls her mother embracing 1960s psychedelia, glam rock and risqué fashion—far from staid. She argues most mothers have lived through multiple cultural revolutions and rejects them as shorthand for boring goods, even quipping: 'These aren’t Keir Starmer’s socks' as a sharper alternative.

articles.title: Yes, a working-class woman will be Labour’s next deputy leader, but what about those still sidelined? | Jennifer Jasmine White
articles.trailText: Until politicians address and improve the lives of all working class women – white and ethnic minority – these advances will feel minimal, says academic Jennifer Jasmine White
articles.summary: With Angela Rayner’s successor in Labour likely another northern working-class woman, Jennifer Jasmine White argues that such representation—exemplified by candidates like Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell who benefited from elite routes—masks the broader plight of most working-class women. Persisting two-child benefit caps, brittle social care and insecure employment disproportionately harm women, especially migrants and ethnic minorities often erased from discourse. White warns that selective definition fuels far-right scapegoating and calls for deputy leadership to champion solidarity across all economically disadvantaged women.

articles.title: With or without a ceasefire, humanitarian aid must enter Gaza. We managed it in previous wars | Moazzam Malik
articles.trailText: Global powers ensured aid during civil wars in Syria and Sudan. We need a ‘Lifeline Rafah’ or more people will starve, says Moazzam Malik, CEO of Save the Children UK
articles.summary: Save the Children UK CEO Moazzam Malik warns at the UN General Assembly that Gaza’s blockade has caused the first famine in the Middle East and is using aid as an occupation tool. He urges creation of an independent cross-border “Lifeline Rafah” under UN or coalition mandate to bypass Israel’s restrictions. Drawing on precedents—2014 Syria cross-border UN mechanism, 1980s Operation Lifeline Sudan, 2008 Myanmar Cyclone Nargis relief—he argues international law and humanitarian imperatives justify negotiated access via Egypt. With over 2 million Palestinians besieged, 90% of homes damaged, healthcare collapsed, 20 000 children killed, no half-measures are acceptable. The UN must act decisively.

articles.title: Think you’re kind? Maybe you’re just being nice. I’ve learned there’s a big difference | Ann Russell
articles.trailText: Like many women, I was conditioned to people-please – until I realised that this was neither helping others, nor myself, says author Ann Russell
articles.summary: Ann Russell describes how being “nice”—seeking approval, avoiding conflict—differs from genuine kindness, which involves doing the right thing regardless of optics. Conditioned to people-please, she recounts her cleaning job: over-treating dogs was easy but unkind; real kindness meant proper training. She contrasts superficial niceness—praising a flawed speech or ignoring lice notices—to true kindness: honest critique and diligent hair checks. Embracing kindness freed her to set boundaries, offer constructive feedback and improve her work and well-being.

articles.title: Starmer finally said it: ‘We recognise Palestine.’ But Gaza desperately needs action – where is that? | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: The British PM and others offered fine words, but after all the horror, many will say too little, too late. Palestinians need unfettered support – and now, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik contends that while the UK’s long-overdue recognition of Palestinian statehood is a necessary correction of historical denial and an important symbolic gesture, it risks remaining a hollow ‘fig leaf’ unless backed by real measures. Britain’s record—endorsing Israel’s cutting of Gaza’s power and water, rejecting a ceasefire, banning pro-Palestine protests and continuing lucrative arms exports—has been timid and reactive. Framing recognition with impossible Israeli preconditions dilutes its impact. To make recognition meaningful, the UK must impose sanctions, trade embargoes and diplomatic isolation to halt the unfolding genocide, annexation and ethnic cleansing.

articles.title: The Guardian view on UK recognition of a Palestinian state: this must be a call to action, not conscience-salving | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The diplomatic groundswell, and Israel’s increasing isolation, come late. They must be the beginning of a renewed effort
articles.summary: After over 65,000 Palestinians, mostly civilians, were killed and starvation stalks Gaza's north, amid stalled peace prospects the UK formally recognized a Palestinian state, conditional on an Israeli ceasefire—critically insufficient. This gesture joins France, Canada and Australia but falls short by using statehood as leverage. The sweeping diplomatic shift is symbolic, hindered by the US blocking UN membership and domestic political calculations. Israel faces growing isolation as evidence of genocide mounts; Palestinians endure looming annexation and displacement. The Guardian urges the UK and EU to employ real leverage—suspend arms, trade privileges and ensure accountability—so recognition nurtures genuine life, nationhood and a viable two-state solution.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Wedgwood’s challenges: potteries face an existential crisis | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial : Further redundancies would be a blow to artisanal craft skills and to the remaining pillars of Staffordshire ceramics
articles.summary: Tracing Wedgwood’s arc from Josiah’s 18th-century jasperware gifted to the Qianlong emperor to a 20th-century Staffordshire powerhouse employing 12,000, this editorial warns that potteries now face an existential crisis as four firms collapse or offshore in two years. Fiskars’ 90-day production pause in Stoke, following decades of debt-fuelled takeovers, Indonesia outsourcing and hundreds of UK job cuts, underscores how brand heritage suffers. Success stories like Burleigh and Emma Bridgewater show consumers pay for “made in England.” The piece calls for urgent policy to protect artisanal skills, noting Labour’s slow industrial measures and ceramic workers’ plea for energy relief.

articles.title: My generation agonises over how to act and what to say. We have to learn to go with the flow | Bertin Huynh
articles.trailText: Thanks to social media, gen Z is more perceived and judged than ever before, and we worry over every word and image. An ancient Chinese text shows there’s a better way
articles.summary: Amid unprecedented information and social-media scrutiny, Gen Z agonises over career choices, investments and daily interactions, obsessing over every word and image. The author turns to Laozi’s 2,000-year-old Daodejing, arguing its cryptic verses—like the water metaphor—reveal language’s limits and counsel wuwei, or ‘effortless action.’ Rather than clutching absolutes or maximising every detail, embracing Daoist paradoxes—soft overcoming hard—frees us to act authentically. Ultimately, only you can walk your path; stop analytic paralysis and just do.

articles.title: After last week, UK ministers should know this: a huge rebellion is coming – we will fight for our children's rights | John Harris
articles.trailText: From mooted Whitehall cost-cutting to the bigoted views of Reform, parents of children with special needs see the latest threats, and we are mobilising, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: With 1.7m SEND pupils and their families alarmed by mooted Whitehall cuts and a looming autumn white paper, parents fear ministers will curb or scrap statutory EHCPs—the legally enforceable Education, Health and Care Plans vital for mainstream inclusion. Grassroots campaign Save Our Children’s Rights amassed 100,000+ petition signatures, 90 MPs joined a Westminster Hall debate, and an education select committee report warned against removing entitlements, urging systemwide support improvements. Against Reform UK’s “overdiagnosis” rhetoric, families are mobilising to defend legal rights ahead of imminent reforms.

articles.title: Eight things I’ve learned in my year of ‘lifting heavy’ | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: I didn’t expect to enjoy heaving chunks of metal. But lifting has paid off for me in surprising ways – and shown I can change my life dramatically, writes Guardian columnist Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington reflects on her first year of weightlifting, a surprise habit that stuck. She highlights luring progress through measurable strength gains and community support, the necessity of rest between grueling sets, and cheering on fellow lifters balancing health conditions or caring roles. She finds value in “failing” safely, embraces bro-language despite cringing, and resists prescriptive fitness dogma. Ultimately, lifting has reshaped her physique and mindset, proving her body and habits remain mutable and igniting confidence that profound personal change is still possible.

articles.title: A historic opportunity for the British left is being thrown away. This very public Your Party row must stop now | Yanis Varoufakis and Ken Loach
articles.trailText: People desperately want and need a party with socialist values. Future generations will be damning if this fails, say economist Yanis Varoufakis and film director Ken Loach
articles.summary: Economist Yanis Varoufakis and director Ken Loach warn that infighting in nascent Your Party threatens a new British socialist force. Spurred by Labour's drift into a moral void - surrender to corporate raiders and the City, disability benefit cuts and complicity over Israel's Gaza offensive - thousands joined the grassroots initiative for a democratically run party. But recent public disputes among organisers have sown confusion and anger, endangering a historic chance to channel disaffection. Varoufakis and Loach urge participants to halt the row, unite in good faith and deliver a member-driven conference to secure the movement's future.

articles.title: Why Trump’s attacks on the Fed’s independence are so dangerous | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates this week. But the aggressive action Trump seeks could dramatically backfire
articles.summary: Steven Greenhouse warns Trump's unprecedented push to fire Fed governor Lisa Cook and coerce rate cuts undermines central bank independence, risking inflation spikes and market turmoil. Despite inheriting strong growth from Biden, Trump's tariffs have slowed the economy and fueled prices. Historical precedents—from Truman and Nixon to Erdogan—show politicized rate cuts lead to runaway inflation and harsh recessions. Bernanke and Yellen caution forced low rates inflate deficits, while Nobel economist Krugman likens Trump's plan to Turkey's 80% inflation crisis. Trump’s assault threatens Fed credibility, risks long-term interest hikes, dollar decline. Courts have blocked his attempt to dismiss Cook, highlighting legal risks.

articles.title: Let’s stop asking why women aren’t having children and ask, for once: why aren’t men? | Rhiannon Lucy Coslett
articles.trailText: On the whole, men I’ve spoken to – like women – want children. But a host of issues, from housing to mental health, is getting in the way, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett argues that as birthrates plummet, debates fixate on why women aren’t having children while sidelining men. She highlights a lack of male fertility data and cites a ‘‘relationship recession’’—fewer partnerships—and widespread delays in parenthood driven by housing costs, labour market precarity, mental health struggles and partner readiness. Parenthood has shifted from a ‘‘cornerstone’’ to a ‘‘capstone’’ life event, requiring financial and emotional stability many can’t achieve. Cosslett calls for research into male fertility influencers, from dating culture to economic barriers, to shape balanced policy responses.

articles.title: Look to Myanmar for a vision of a world where authoritarians have unfettered power | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The brutality and repression there highlight the failings of a dysfunctional world order. Unless we do better, this is the future, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: After a 2021 military coup in Myanmar, the Min Aung Hlaing junta has waged brutal airstrikes on civilians, including a boarding school bombing, and carried out crimes against humanity, displacing four million people and intensifying the Rohingya crisis. Despite UN investigations and planned sham elections in December, China, Russia, India and a wavering US shield the regime while ASEAN remains divided. The situation exemplifies global dysfunction: rising authoritarianism, impunity for war crimes, stalled humanitarian aid and weakened multilateral institutions, warning of a post-democratic future if the West fails to act.

articles.title: I have a dirty TV secret – and there’s a 50/50 chance that you do too | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: More than half of people in the UK exaggerate, fabricate or downplay what they watch and pretend they’re into documentaries or serious drama. I am as guilty as they come, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: A UK survey finds 54% of people lie about their TV habits—claiming to watch documentaries or prestige drama—to seem smarter. Polly Hudson confesses her own guilty pleasure: the Real Housewives reality franchise, from New York through every spin-off, including a new London edition. Despite high-profile advocates like John Oliver, Brenda Fricker and Michelle Obama, superfans hide their obsession, only gathering openly at events like BravoCon (35,000 attendees). Producer Andy Cohen explains viewers love judging on-screen morality, driving the secrecy around reality-TV fandom.

articles.title: Coalition denial makes Labor seem reasonable on climate – but neither is ambitious enough | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: Treasury estimates a ‘disorderly’ energy transition would result in an Australian economy that’s $1.2tn smaller. Neither major party has the policies to prevent that
articles.summary: Zoe Daniel argues that neither Labor nor the Coalition offers the ambition needed for Australia’s net-zero transition. Labor’s pragmatic 62–70% 2030 range is undercut by continued fossil fuel support, while the Coalition’s climate denial and policy flip-flops deter renewable investment. Treasury warns a disorderly shift could shrink GDP by A$1.2 trn; CSIRO predicts 0.7% lower growth and 50% lower wages by 2060 under slow action. Deloitte and business groups say stronger targets could deliver hundreds of billions in extra GDP. Without clear, stable policy, Australia risks economic loss, energy insecurity and regional instability.

articles.title: The new iPhone is an emblem of our miserable minimalist era | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: The barely there iPhone Air is in line with trends in tech, design and art – unsullied by thought, risk or humor
articles.summary: Dave Schilling critiques Apple’s new ultra-thin iPhone Air as the inevitable apex of our ‘miserable minimalist’ era, where tech, art and design adopt a bland scarcity that forgoes thought, risk or humor. He contrasts its surgical thinness with the candy-colored iMac of 1998, likening today’s aesthetic to Jamie Lloyd’s barebones Evita and Godot productions that erase context. Minimalism, he warns, has become a hollow status symbol—a pristine facade masking chaos, erasure and loss of control.

articles.title: Even Tucker Carlson is worried about Trump’s free speech crackdown | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The former Fox News host is speaking out against the administration’s response to the Charlie Kirk shooting
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi warns that the Trump administration is exploiting Charlie Kirk’s killing to erode First Amendment rights—urging State Department reporting of foreigners who “rationalize” his death, visa denials, Pam Bondi’s DOJ “hate speech” targeting and VP JD Vance’s call to report critics to employers. FEMA staff and pundits like Matthew Dowd, Jimmy Kimmel and Karen Attiah have been suspended or fired over Kirk-related posts. Mahdawi cautions that an unofficial “Department of Thought Control” may soon emerge. Even former Fox host Tucker Carlson argues any future hate-speech laws would justify civil disobedience, since controlling speech equates to controlling thought.

articles.title: History teaches us that authoritarians use any excuse to seize power | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: Nazis used the 1933 Reichstag blaze to justify snuffing out civil liberties. In the US, the calls for a crackdown have already begun
articles.summary: Judith Levine warns that, like the Nazis exploiting the 1933 Reichstag fire to suspend civil liberties and crush opposition, the Trump administration is using Charlie Kirk’s 2025 assassination as a pretext to politicize government power, vilify and target the left, threaten media and academics, and expand repressive measures—from pressured FCC actions and DOJ threats to proposed racketeering charges and expanded ICE authority. Drawing parallels to Germany’s emergency decree and Enabling Act, she cautions that without popular resistance such assaults could erode US democracy.

articles.title: As Hollywood mourns Robert Redford, why do we still struggle with the idea of male beauty?  | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: The superstar never wanted to be a sex symbol. But we don’t have a language to discuss what great beauty can feel like for men, says Guardian newsletter editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Jason Okundaye argues that as Hollywood mourns Robert Redford’s death at 89, his celebrated “all-American” looks both propelled and pigeonholed him—from the Sundance Kid to All the President’s Men and founding the Sundance festival. The piece explores why we lack a language for male beauty, showing how Redford, Keanu Reeves, Sterling K. Brown and musician D’Angelo have resisted objectification and typecasting. Okundaye critiques the cultural tendency to pit attractiveness against talent and urges a richer vocabulary to honor male beauty alongside skill and substance.

articles.title: Coldplay preaching peace and love to Charlie Kirk is all well and good. But would it hurt artists to take a stand? | Elle Hunt
articles.trailText: At Wembley, Chris Martin exhorted the crowd to ‘send love anywhere you wanna send it’. But half-hearted word salad won’t stop the rise of hate, says freelance journalist Elle Hunt
articles.summary: At Wembley, Hunt lauds Coldplay’s dazzling stage production—3D effects, Femi Kuti, Palestinian-Chilean singer Elyanna and a Venezuelan orchestra—and their environmental philanthropy, despite ten studio albums and two decades of hits. Yet she faults Chris Martin’s broad appeals to "send love anywhere," including to Charlie Kirk’s family, as empty word salad that skirts the asymmetry of suffering in Ukraine, Israel-Palestine and global hate. Contrasting more outspoken female artists, Hunt urges bands with middle-British, conservative audiences to take clear political stands instead of platitudes.

articles.title: I’m a British MP, a doctor and Jewish. This is what happened when I tried to enter Israel | Peter Prinsley
articles.trailText: Barred from entry on ‘public security’ grounds, I had a moment to reflect on how far the country has fallen, says British MP Peter Prinsley
articles.summary: Labour MP Peter Prinsley, a 67-year-old Jewish former ENT surgeon, was denied entry into Israel on “public security” grounds while on a CAABU humanitarian delegation to assess Palestinian healthcare in the West Bank. Stopped at the Sheikh Hussein crossing, he witnessed the parched Jordan River and no man’s land, and laments Israel’s drift from its founding democratic, pluralistic ideals into isolation under its current government, warning that blocking parliamentarians hinders transparency and prospects for peace.

articles.title: I have now been a journalist for 40 years. The forces ranged against my profession have never been so powerful | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: Once, I believed that humanity’s problem was an information deficit. Now, I know you can’t speak truth to power if power controls your words, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Monbiot reflects on four decades in journalism, tracing the BBC’s once-robust investigative ethos under Alasdair Milne and its abrupt suppression under Thatcher, which taught him that financial power often stifles truth. After freelance work exposing corruption and environmental harm, and futile attempts to place stories with right-wing papers, he joined the Guardian—the rare mainstream outlet that still challenges elites. He criticizes today’s media as captive to billionaire interests but highlights a hopeful resurgence in citizen-driven, local news platforms.

articles.title: The Guardian view on criminal justice reform: community sentencing can’t be done on the cheap | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The chief inspector of probation is right to be anxious about the service’s growing workload
articles.summary: HM chief inspector Martin Jones warns England and Wales face rising violent crime unless the probation service is bolstered: roughly 100,000 offenders currently lack proper supervision. With prison overcrowding and high reoffending, Labour-backed sentencing reforms favour community measures and electronic tagging, backed by a £700m investment to 2028-29. But scaling up probation without addressing staff shortages and experience gaps risks public safety, as seen in high-profile cases (Damien Bendall, Zara Aleena). The editorial urges ministers to honour promises, invest in recruitment and training, and treat probation with the seriousness long neglected.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Adolescence cleaning up at the Emmys: the importance of grassroots drama training | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Theatre schools are in crisis. More must be done to nurture young talent like Owen Cooper across the country
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues that the Emmy success of 15-year-old Owen Cooper in 'Adolescence' spotlights the vital role of grassroots drama schools and working-class representation, praising community hubs like Manchester's Drama MOB. With historic institutions such as Bristol Old Vic and Rose Bruford facing closure and GCSE and A-level drama uptake plummeting, access to training is in crisis. Despite award-winning shows by Michaela Coel and Stephen Graham, private education still dominates. The government has pledged to reverse arts-education cuts, but more regional and national support is needed to nurture diverse talent.

articles.title: Trump has dragged the US to the abyss and Nigel Farage would do the same to Britain. Here’s how to stop him
articles.trailText: It’s not too late to puncture the Reform leader’s populist myth. His ‘make Britain great again’ act is out of step with the British people, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland argues that Trump’s rapid assault on US institutions—sidelining courts, gagging critics like Jimmy Kimmel, suing the New York Times and labeling opponents ‘extremists’—reveals an authoritarian impulse. In Britain Nigel Farage’s Reform Party echoes his ‘Make Britain Great Again’ populism but diverges radically from public opinion: a majority regret Brexit, back the ECHR, and reject his immigration scare tactics. The Tommy Robinson march and Elon Musk’s incendiary video signal growing far-right energy. To prevent a similar slide, mainstream parties must unite to expose Farage’s fringe views and undercut his claim to speak for the silent majority.

articles.title: America’s language of extremity is shocking to Australians. With local radicals on the march, we have to push back | Van Badham
articles.trailText: If you’re wondering why you feel emotionally assaulted every time you click a social media app it’s not just due to the content of US news
articles.summary: Australian columnist Van Badham argues that the spectacle and extremity of US political discourse—B-movie theatrics from FBI dramas to Trump’s threats—shocks Australians accustomed to regulated public speech. She contrasts Australia’s implied constitutional free speech limits and incremental hate-speech laws with America’s expansive First Amendment culture, warning imported radical online rhetoric exploits lax platform regulation, undermining Australia’s cultural sovereignty. To defend social norms and stem rising local radicalism inspired by US extremism, she calls for democratic controls on online speech.

articles.title: When even Ben & Jerry’s can’t speak out, it’s clear: the era of corporate responsibility is over | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: Jerry himself has left the ice-cream company, alleging it had been silenced. He’s yet another casualty of corporate kowtowing
articles.summary: Political scientist Austin Sarat warns the era of corporate social responsibility is over as firms mute dissent under authoritarianism. After corporations suspended Jimmy Kimmel for criticizing MAGA, Ben & Jerry’s co-founder Jerry Greenfield resigned, accusing parent Unilever—owner since 2000—of “silencing” its progressive stances on racial justice, a Gaza ceasefire and US–Israel policy. B&J’s 2024 lawsuit alleges Unilever threatened to dismantle its independent board and ousted CEO David Stever for pursuing a “social mission.” Sarat links this retreat to the rise of “authoritarian capitalism,” from Orbán’s Hungary to Trump’s America. Brands no longer risk profits for principle.

articles.title: Trump’s visit revealed a stark truth: Britain feels more than ever like a country stuck in the past | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: The pageantry highlighted the fact that we have no vision for our future, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Britain’s lavish state visit for Donald Trump exposed a nation enthralled by pageantry but lacking future vision. Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins laments the contrast between ritualistic ceremony—carriages, white ties and bear-skinned guards—and a faltering NHS, unstable courts, and Treasury. He critiques PM Keir Starmer’s weak leadership, revolving-door ministries, archaic parliamentary rituals, a bloated House of Lords and endless public inquiries. While Trump’s tour bypassed central power hubs, the pomp boosted tourism more than policy. Jenkins warns that Britain excels at rehearsing history—prolonged inquiries, medieval rituals—but struggles to reform services, local democracy or harness AI and social media regulation for the future.

articles.title: Donald Trump’s base is fraying. Are Democrats up to the moment? | Lloyd Green
articles.trailText: The president’s approval rating is underwater, with a new poll showing plunging Latino support
articles.summary: President Trump’s approval remains underwater, with generic polling at –7 to –8% and Hispanic disapproval at 65% (Black Americans at 84%, White at 50–47). Following Trump’s first popular-vote plurality in 2024, rising youth unemployment (10.8% overall; Black youth 14.3%, Hispanic youth 12.6%), looming healthcare cuts and persistent inflation are fueling buyer’s remorse. While Democrats lead narrowly on the generic ballot before the 2026 midterms, they risk missing the moment without a cohesive economic message. Latino voters, once more fluid than assumed, prioritized kitchen-table issues over social themes, swinging south Texas seats to Republicans.

articles.title: Trump’s take on a court decision on tariffs is bonkers – even for him | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: The president’s claim that undermining his tariffs would ‘literally destroy’ the country gets the situation backwards
articles.summary: After an appeals court on August 29 ruled Trump overstepped his authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act by imposing blanket 10–50% tariffs on 70+ countries, Trump blasted that striking them down would “literally destroy” the US and turn it into a Third World nation. Economists note the tariffs have raised inflation, dragged growth and approval ratings lower. The court said only Congress can levy tariffs. Trump’s rant aims to pressure the Supreme Court’s six conservative justices to uphold his tariffs. Blocking them would curb inflation, protect consumers and restore the US’s pre-tariff economic strength.

articles.title: Yanking Jimmy Kimmel’s show is a new low for free speech in America | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: Kimmel’s sudden defenestration may be a political success for Trump but it’s a dire sign for free speech in America
articles.summary: ABC abruptly pulled Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show after his monologue denouncing the political exploitation of Charlie Kirk’s murder. Trump-appointed FCC chair Brendan Carr threatened license revocations, Nexstar dropped the program and Disney complied. Free-speech advocates like PEN America and Columbia’s Knight First Amendment Institute condemned this as authoritarian censorship. The episode follows ABC’s settlement of Trump’s defamation suit over George Stephanopoulos, CBS’s payout in its Harris interview case and media owners’ rightward shifts to curry favor. Experts warn such capitulations embolden political pressure, undermining the First Amendment and democratic discourse.

articles.title: Who should be Labour’s deputy leader? Whoever can tell a good Labour story – and take the fight to Reform | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The political differences between Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell are slight. What the party needs is someone able to unite and persuade, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues the Labour deputy leadership contest between Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell offers a vital chance to redefine the party’s purpose. Phillipson’s record on early-years education, free school meals and taxing private schools contrasts with Powell’s outsider appeal to disaffected members, yet their policy differences are slight. Facing dire polls (20%) and Farage’s Reform at 31%, they must forge a coherent narrative linking nationalisation, green investment, renters’ rights and tackle child poverty by scrapping the two-child benefit cap. The victor must use persuasive storytelling—not merely delivery—to unite the party, protect democracy, call out racism and counter xenophobic populism.

articles.title: After the far-right mass rally in London, Britain must learn lessons from abroad – and fast | Cas Mudde
articles.trailText: This is no time for complacent exceptionalism. The UK is part of the fourth phase of the far right in the postwar era, and its politicians must respond, says political scientist Cas Mudde
articles.summary: This piece by Cas Mudde argues that Britain’s mainstream parties must abandon exceptionalism after Tommy Robinson’s “Unite the Kingdom” rally exposed the country’s entry into the fourth, globalised phase of the postwar far right. Mudde urges Labour to drop anti-immigration mimicry, and warns Conservatives against believing Brexit halted extremist growth. He highlights Reform UK’s polling lead over both Tories and Labour as evidence of political fragmentation. The rally’s violence, foreign speakers, and media spin show UK democrats need to learn from continental Europe and embrace coalition-building with centrist and left allies.

articles.title: Is there anything Labour can do to save itself from disaster? Our panel responds – part two
articles.trailText: Over a year into power, Starmer’s government is floundering – but it still has time on its side. In the second of a two-part series, our panelists suggest ways of reversing the slide
articles.summary: Over a year into power, Starmer’s government falters; four panellists propose remedies: Rory Stewart urges fewer reshuffles and a constitutional revolution—mayoral devolution, PR voting, citizen assemblies—to rebuild institutional memory and incentives. Mariana Mazzucato warns against unfettered AI investment, advocating conditional state partnerships to foster UK capacity, workers’ input and public value. Shaista Aziz calls for a principled reset on Gaza, including arms embargoes and distancing from Israeli actions. Alan Finlayson diagnoses Labour’s lack of ideology and rhetoric: he urges coherent narratives, open public debates and empowering MPs and members to frame a credible vision beyond managerialist politics.

articles.title: Bow-tied snooker players and hushed commentary: the joys of Pot Black | Nova Weetman
articles.trailText: We’d curl up on the couch, waiting for that jaunty theme song. Some games would be so close I worried I’d stop breathing
articles.summary: Nova Weetman recalls bonding with her father in 1970s Australia over BBC’s Pot Black snooker on ABC, despite neither understanding rules. The bow-tied players, hushed commentary and jaunty theme song hooked her. Though she later preferred impulsive pub-table pool in Melbourne, a gallery painting titled “Snooker” reignited her childhood passion. She rediscovered vintage episodes, fascinated by David Attenborough’s 1969 push for color TV to showcase vibrant balls on green felt. The artwork now hangs in her home, a daily link to the show that transformed snooker’s popularity.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s state visit to Britain: plenty of glitter, but this was gilt, not gold | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The hyperbole is in sharp contrast to the actual achievements, but in this new era minimising damage and buying time look like wins
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial critiques Donald Trump’s unprecedented second state visit to Britain as extravagant ceremony overshadowing scant tangible gains. Despite Sir Keir Starmer’s praise for a tech memorandum promising US investment and AI collaboration, UK tariffs remain unchanged, and billions pledged pale against global spending. The visit showcased pageantry—from golden carriages to bespoke red boxes—while protests and arrests under the Malicious Communications Act highlighted domestic unease. Trump’s reluctance on Russia, calls for more fossil fuel extraction, and migration militarization underscored policy divergence. Britain’s deference, the editorial warns, risks reducing it to a technological vassal, trading impact for symbolism.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Lib Dem conference: speaking for parts of England | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Sir Ed Davey’s party has plenty to look forward to, but also difficult choices to make
articles.summary: Sir Ed Davey’s Liberal Democrats enter their Bournemouth conference buoyed by historic 72-seat haul and 2025 local election growth but constrained by a 14% poll average and heavy reliance on remain-voting areas amid Reform UK’s rise. The editorial warns of a strategic crossroads: whether to defend former Conservative marginals or court disillusioned Labour voters with a compelling, costed economic and environmental programme. A strong showing next year could push Lib Dem MPs toward 100 and make them kingmakers in a potential hung parliament.

articles.title: Jimmy Kimmel, Stephen Colbert … who is the next to be silenced? | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: When a regime can use the power of the law to punish speech because it does not like that speech’s content, then speech is not free
articles.summary: After FCC commissioner Brendan Carr threatened regulatory action over Jimmy Kimmel’s critique of Charlie Kirk’s death and MAGA ties, ABC and Disney suspended his show indefinitely—prompted in part by Nexstar affiliates refusing to air it amid a $6.2 billion Tegna merger. This corporate capitulation under government pressure, known as jawboning, follows Stephen Colbert’s recent CBS cancellation after a Trump defamation settlement. Moira Donegan argues that using legal threats to silence comedians and journalists, and media companies’ fear-driven compliance, represent an unprecedented First Amendment crisis under the Trump regime.

articles.title: Jeff Hiller and Katherine LaNasa’s surprise Emmy wins buoy those of us who also don’t fit a template to continue The Slog | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: Sorry to my enemies, but little boosts like this help stop me from abandoning my dreams
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw celebrates the surprise Emmy wins of character actor Jeff Hiller (Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series for Somebody Somewhere) and veteran Katherine LaNasa (Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for The Pitt). Both in their late 40s/50s, they’ve spent decades in minor roles before earning recognition: Hiller’s portrayal of Joel defied expectations against bigger names, while LaNasa’s victory—following breast cancer treatment—underscores meaningful art. Shaw, a 42-year-old comedy writer, draws inspiration, viewing their late-career triumphs as proof that perseverance outside conventional molds can pay off and buoy the creative dreams of those still grinding in TV and theatre.

articles.title: Trump has gone home but Britain’s problems will remain. Starmer’s invitation was a big mistake | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: All the pomp and circumstance can’t distract from the hate and division. The PM must summon the courage to act, says Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: Frances Ryan criticizes Keir Starmer’s decision to host Donald Trump’s state visit, arguing pomp and ceremony masked his divisive record. Despite protests and images of Trump beside a child trafficker on Windsor Castle, ministers rolled out gilded carriages, military honours and the Red Arrows to secure trade deals. Parliament’s delayed response to far-right marches and anti-immigrant rhetoric revealed a reluctance to name racism, leaving figures like Sadiq Khan to condemn hate. Ryan urges Britain to ditch realpolitik, summon political courage and confront xenophobia and extremism rather than stage theatrical gaslighting.

articles.title: Trump has forgotten his oath of office. History will not remember him kindly | Corey Brettschneider
articles.trailText: When faced with a crisis, presidents can inflame divisions or unify the nation. Trump is taking the path of Andrew Johnson and not Lincoln
articles.summary: After Charlie Kirk’s death, Donald Trump forsook his oath by blaming a nebulous “radical left,” weaponizing tragedy to polarize rather than unify the nation. Corey Brettschneider likens Trump’s tactics to Andrew Johnson’s post–Lincoln divisiveness—impeachment and Reconstruction’s rollback—contrasting them with Lincoln’s “better angels,” Bush’s outreach to Muslims, Clinton’s post-Oklahoma unity and LBJ’s post–MLK call for justice. Instead of condemning violence, affirming the rule of law and equal application, Trump deepens divides with broad scapegoating and threats against opponents, mocking the oath he swore.

articles.title: As boys shift to the right, we are seeing the rise of the ‘new chill girl’ | Naomi Beinart
articles.trailText: Even in comparatively liberal spaces, such as my high school, girls who wince at locker room talk risk exclusion
articles.summary: Since Trump’s return in 2024, high-school girls face a “new chill girl” dilemma: speak out against racist, sexist and homophobic jokes and be labeled “annoying,” or stay silent to seem “chill.” A cultural shift—Disney’s removal of a transgender character, a ban on email pronouns, a drop in DEI reporting and a surge in “trad wife” influencers—normalises conservative, illiberal views. Pew finds 45% of girls 13–17 feel intense social pressure. This climate hurts progressive teens, deepening gender divides and stifling women’s voices and future power.

articles.title: I’ve seen horrible things at football matches – but what landed on the pitch last week was the worst | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: When a mysterious object fell from the sky mid-game, I knew it was a portent of doom. The surprise was finding out who chucked it there, writes Guardian columnist Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: During West Brom’s home game vs Derby County, play was halted when half a dead pigeon landed mid-pitch—a leftover dropped by the club’s resident peregrine falcon. Dominating the match but failing to score, West Brom’s players and fans took the grim avian fragment as an ominous sign. After the stoppage, Derby scored with their only on-target shot, securing a 1-0 victory. Columnist Adrian Chiles reflects on the surreal incident—wondering if the falcon could be trained as a macabre weapon against opponents—and laments returning home dejected after the half-pigeon of doom sealed West Brom’s fate.

articles.title: Trump’s suit against the New York Times is nonsense. Yet it poses a grave threat | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The president won’t prevail in court. But his cases against media companies have a potential chilling effect on criticism of the government
articles.summary: Robert Reich argues that Donald Trump’s defamation lawsuit against the New York Times—and his similar suits against WSJ, ABC, CBS—are frivolous but intended to intimidate the press. Despite New York Times v. Sullivan’s high bar for public-figure defamation, these suits impose high legal costs and risk chilling scrutiny of government. Corporate media have already settled or self-censored under threat of FCC action. Reich calls for barring presidents from defamation suits and stricter antitrust oversight of media ownership to protect democracy.

articles.title: ‘A slap in the face’: our expert panel on Australia’s 2035 emissions target
articles.trailText: Six experts respond to Labor’s plans for agriculture, resources, the built environment, industry, transport and energy. What did it get right and what more needs to be done?
articles.summary: Six experts condemn Australia’s 62-70% by-2035 emissions target as inadequate and riskier across key sectors. Agriculture: farmers face extreme heat, drought and demand stronger fossil-fuel cuts, renewables and soil carbon incentives. Resources: calls for genuine fugitive emissions monitoring, carbon pricing, strict offsets, caution on costly CCS and linked sector modelling. Built environment: retrofit leaky sub-2-star homes and regulate embodied carbon. Industry: needs tailored electrification, renewable fuels, border carbon adjustments and energy-efficiency credits. Transport: lacking a sector target, needs EV infrastructure, heavy-vehicle incentives and fuel policy. Energy: accelerate renewables, transmission and rooftop solar with landlord mandates.

articles.title: AI could never replace my authors. But, without regulation, it will ruin publishing as we know it | Jonny Geller
articles.trailText: Basic principles need to be enshrined to protect the sacred craft of storytelling from this automated onslaught, says literary agent Jonny Geller
articles.summary: Literary agent Jonny Geller warns that unregulated AI, trained on scraped copyrighted texts, poses an existential threat to authors and the £11bn UK publishing sector, eroding storytelling’s human craft. While AI tools like research assistants or translation models can aid writers if used transparently, Big Tech’s opaque data scraping—excused by “fair use”—undermines creators. Geller calls for an Artists’ Rights Charter mandating explicit permission, attribution, source disclosure, opt-out and withdrawal rights, clear AI-content labels, and reinforced domestic and international copyright to safeguard cultural heritage.

articles.title: This news just in: we hoped the middle- and upper-class capture of the media would lessen. It’s got worse | Carl Cullinane
articles.trailText: Since our last survey, we find more columnists, podcasters and executives are from privileged backgrounds. That’s too narrow a segment of society, says Carl Cullinane, director of research and policy at the Sutton Trust
articles.summary: The Sutton Trust’s latest survey reveals a worsening class imbalance in UK media: despite just 7% of Britons attending private schools, 50% of newspaper columnists, 47% of political commentators, 45% of leading podcasters and 38% of BBC executives are privately educated—a rise since 2019. Over 40% of columnists and commentators attended Oxbridge. Podcasting remains dominated by established voices, and BBC leadership is underrepresented amid licence-fee debates and Ofcom findings of class dissatisfaction. Structural barriers—fewer local outlets, unpaid internships, precarious contracts—hinder social mobility. By contrast, new online creators are more diverse: only 18% private‐educated and 68% from state comprehensives.

articles.title: I quit the US and Britain seemed like a sanctuary from Trump’s Maga movement. Now I wonder, for how long | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: I was the envy of the friends I’d left behind. Now it seems prudent to assess how much that nativism will truly take root here, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Emma Brockes moved from the US to Britain in 2024 anticipating refuge from Trump’s MAGAism under a new Starmer government. Now she sees Nigel Farage’s Reform UK channeling Brexit frustration and Tommy Robinson’s Unite the Kingdom rally echoing US right-wing populism. She derides Farage as a frivolous “grinning fool” mocked in Congress, contrasting his ineptitude with Trump’s mass-communication skills. Brockes compares the rapid rise of UK nativism to Trump’s ascent, noting cultural differences—like weaker evangelical influence and distinct local issues—yet fears enough followers could blur divergences. As Trump visits, she wonders if Britain’s nascent MAGA-style movement will deepen or dissipate.

articles.title: Labour is in a mess. Is there anything Starmer can do to turn things around? Our panel responds – part one
articles.trailText: Over a year into power, Keir Starmer’s government is floundering. But it still has a large parliamentary majority and time on its side — here’s what it could do, says our first group of panelists
articles.summary: Columnists John Harris, Ann Pettifor and Simon Woolley warn that a year into power Starmer’s government flounders, its 1.5m homes pledge looking fragile, without landmark reforms. Harris demands a social housing surge—Shelter’s 90,000-homes-a-year benchmark—leveraging local Labour councils to revive public building. Pettifor urges a “big green state” overhaul: create a Department for National Strategy, boost green infrastructure spending, establish an Inflation Control Office and remake the Bank of England’s mandate. Woolley calls for a unifying immigration speech celebrating diversity alongside investment in post-industrial communities to blunt nationalist appeals.

articles.title: It’s come to this: Keir Starmer is now just the warm-up act for Nigel Farage | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: As Labour flounders and dabbles in the politics of hatred to gain a point or two, it is those far from power who will suffer most, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty criticises Keir Starmer’s Labour government for normalising far-right racism by pandering to anti-immigrant sentiment. He contrasts the brazen 100,000-strong “send them back” rally with 1970s bigotry, arguing today’s extremists lack shame. Starmer’s tepid condemnations, strategic silence on prejudice and an advert boasting of 35,000 deportations enable figures like Nigel Farage and Tommy Robinson. With migration demonised for polling points, the Overton window shifts right, threatening vulnerable migrants. Chakrabortty warns Labour’s centrist tactics risk empowering hard-right narratives, with real consequences for asylum seekers and ethnic minorities far beyond political point-scoring.

articles.title: France should have recognised Palestinian statehood years ago. The cynic in me asks: why now? | Rokhaya Diallo
articles.trailText: Weakened domestically, Emmanuel Macron wants an international legacy. Yet still, he does nothing to sanction Israel, says Guardian Europe columnist Rokhaya Diallo
articles.summary: In September 2025, amid domestic turmoil, President Macron announced France’s intention to recognise Palestinian statehood, provoking harsh rebukes from Israeli PM Netanyahu and US ambassador Charles Kushner, who warned against rising antisemitism. Critics highlight France’s failure to sanction Israel over its actions in Gaza and the West Bank, military support for Israel, and systemic racism at home. While 147 UN states recognise Palestine and calls grow amid alleged genocide and apartheid, Diallo argues Macron’s timing is driven by a desire for an international legacy rather than genuine support.
